text: Chapter 10
label: TITLE

text: Stable Isotopes of Transition and Post-Transition Metals
label: BODY

text: as Tracers in Environmental Studies
label: BODY

text: Thomas D. Bullen
label: BODY

text: Abstract The transition and post-transition metals,
label: BODY

text: which include the elements in Groups 3–12 of the
label: BODY

text: Periodic Table, have a broad range of geological and
label: BODY

text: biological roles as well as industrial applications and
label: BODY

text: thus are widespread in the environment. Interdiscip-
label: BODY

text: linary research over the past decade has resulted in a
label: BODY

text: broad understanding of the isotope systematics of this
label: BODY

text: important group of elements and revealed largely
label: BODY

text: unexpected variability in isotope composition for
label: BODY

text: natural materials. Signiﬁcant kinetic and equilibrium
label: BODY

text: isotope fractionation has been observed for redox sen-
label: BODY

text: sitive metals such as iron, chromium, copper, molyb-
label: BODY

text: denum and mercury, and for metals that are not redox
label: BODY

text: sensitive in nature such as cadmium and zinc. In the
label: BODY

text: environmental sciences, the isotopes are increasingly
label: BODY

text: being used to understand important issues such as
label: BODY

text: tracing of metal contaminant sources and fates, unra-
label: BODY

text: veling metal redox cycles, deciphering metal nutrient
label: BODY

text: pathways and cycles, and developing isotope biosigna-
label: BODY

text: tures that can indicate the role of biological activity in
label: BODY

text: ancient and modern planetary systems.
label: BODY

text: 10.1 Introduction
label: BODY

text: The transition metals form a geochemically and isoto-
label: BODY

text: pically complex and interesting group of elements
label: BODY

text: clustered in the center of the periodic table. The term
label: BODY

text: transition metal, according to the International Union
label: BODY

text: of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), refers to an
label: BODY

text: element whose atom has an incomplete d sub-shell or
label: BODY

text: which can give rise to cations with an incomplete d
label: BODY

text: sub-shell. As shown in Fig. 10.1, according to this
label: BODY

text: deﬁnition transition metals occur in Groups 1B and
label: BODY

text: 3B-8B of the periodic table, and the transition metals
label: BODY

text: across the periodic table have progressively increasing
label: BODY

text: d-shell electron occupancy up to a maximum of 9.
label: BODY

text: A characteristic of transition metals is that they gener-
label: BODY

text: ally exhibit two or more oxidation states, which as a
label: BODY

text: consequence often leads to differences in the stable
label: BODY

text: isotope composition of the chemical compounds and
label: BODY

text: aqueous species they form. Transition metals for
label: BODY

text: which signiﬁcant variation of stable isotope com-
label: BODY

text: position in natural materials has been demonstrated
label: BODY

text: include chromium (Cr), iron (Fe), nickel (Ni), copper
label: BODY

text: (Cu), molybdenum (Mo) and silver (Ag).
label: BODY

text: The above deﬁnition of transition metal speciﬁ-
label: BODY

text: cally excludes the Group 2B elements zinc (Zn),
label: BODY

text: cadmium (Cd) and mercury (Hg), which are often
label: BODY

text: referred to as post-transition metals. These metals
label: BODY

text: have the d shell ﬁlled and thus generally occur as
label: BODY

text: cations only in the þ2 oxidation state. However, it is
label: BODY

text: useful to include the post-transition metals in any
label: BODY

text: discussion of transition metals, as they provide inter-
label: BODY

text: esting similarities and contrasts in chemical behavior,
label: BODY

text: are subject to change in redox state either naturally
label: BODY

text: (e.g. Hg) or under anthropogenic inﬂuence (e.g. Zn,
label: BODY

text: Cd) and display signiﬁcant variation of stable isotope
label: BODY

text: composition in natural materials.
label: BODY

text: Given this broad perspective, a description of the
label: BODY

text: isotope systematics of the transition and post-transition
label: BODY

text: metals is given here, including general isotopic distri-
label: BODY

text: bution, examples of processes leading to stable isotope
label: BODY

text: fractionation, and chemical properties pertinent to the
label: BODY

text: discussion of stable isotope variability observed in
label: BODY

text: natural materials. Rather than providing a comprehen-
label: BODY

text: sive treatment of these issues, the intent here is to
label: BODY

text: provide a general understanding of how the transition
label: BODY

text: metal stable isotopes behave in Earth’s hydrosphere
label: BODY

text: T.D. Bullen (*)
label: BODY

text: U.S. Geological Survey, MS 420, 345 Middleﬁeld Road,
label: BODY

text: Menlo Park, CA 94025, USA
label: BODY

text: M. Baskaran (ed.), Handbook of Environmental Isotope Geochemistry, Advances in Isotope Geochemistry,
label: BODY

text: DOI 10.1007/978-3-642-10637-8_10, # Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2011
label: BODY

text: and atmosphere that are the venue of environmental
label: BODY

text: research. Familiarity with the material in this section
label: BODY

text: will help readers who are not well versed in stable
label: BODY

text: isotope geochemistry to better appreciate the speciﬁc
label: BODY

text: applications discussed in the later part of the chapter.
label: BODY

text: 10.1.1 Chromium (Cr)
label: BODY

text: Chromium is an important trace element, particularly
label: BODY

text: in ultramaﬁc and maﬁc rock minerals, and is a major
label: BODY

text: element in several minerals such as chromite (FeCr2O4)
label: BODY

text: of the spinel group, uvarovite (Ca3Cr2(SiO4)3 of
label: BODY

text: the garnet group, and crocoite (PbCrO4). Chromium
label: BODY

text: has numerous industrial applications, including use in
label: BODY

text: electroplating, in leather tanning, as pigment in paint,
label: BODY

text: and as an anticorrosion agent. Chromium is stable
label: BODY

text: at the Earth’s surface in two oxidation states: Cr6+
label: BODY

text: (Cr(VI)), commonly referred to as hexavalent Cr,
label: BODY

text: and Cr3+ (Cr(III)), commonly referred to as trivalent
label: BODY

text: Cr. Cr(VI) is a strong oxidant, and occurs mainly as
label: BODY

text: the toxic, water-soluble oxyanions chromate (CrO4
label: BODY

text: and bichromate (HCr2O7
label: BODY

text: 1-). Cr(III) is nontoxic and is
label: BODY

text: insoluble in water.
label: BODY

text: Chromium has four stable isotopes: 50Cr (4.35%),
label: BODY

text: that for Cr and other elements discussed below that
label: BODY

text: relative percentages of the isotopes are the values
label: BODY

text: recommended by IUPAC to represent average terres-
label: BODY

text: trial abundances. Igneous rocks have a very restricted
label: BODY

text: range of 53Cr/52Cr which on average is about 0.12‰
label: BODY

text: (parts per thousand) less than that of NIST (National
label: BODY

text: Institute of Standards and Technology) 979 Cr metal
label: BODY

text: (Schoenberg et al. 2008). Presently the measured
label: BODY

text: range of 53Cr/52Cr in natural materials is ~6‰, essen-
label: BODY

text: tially reﬂecting the range measured for naturally occu-
label: BODY

text: rring Cr(VI) in groundwater (Izbicki et al. 2008). Both
label: BODY

text: inorganic and microbially mediated reduction of Cr
label: BODY

text: (VI) to Cr(III) have been shown to result in isotope
label: BODY

text: fractionation, with breakage of the strong Cr-O bond
label: BODY

text: in chromate and bichromate appearing to be the rate
label: BODY

text: limiting step (Ellis et al. 2002; Sikora et al. 2008).
label: BODY

text: During reduction of Cr(VI), the product Cr(III) formed
label: BODY

text: at any step of the process is 3–4‰ lighter than co-
label: BODY

text: existing remnant Cr(VI). The fact that the oxidized
label: BODY

text: species, Cr(VI), is heavier than the reduced species,
label: BODY

text: Cr(III), is consistent with observations for other redox-
label: BODY

text: sensitive elements such as selenium (Johnson et al.
label: BODY

text: 2000; Johnson 2011) and mercury (Bergquist and
label: BODY

text: Blum 2009; Blum 2011). While oxidation of Cr(III)
label: BODY

text: to Cr(VI) is also likely to cause stable isotope fraction-
label: BODY

text: ation (Schauble 2004), this phenomenon has yet to be
label: BODY

text: rigorously demonstrated. Sorption of chromate and
label: BODY

text: bichromate on Fe- and Al-oxyhydroxides has only a
label: BODY

text: negligible instantaneous effect on the distribution of Cr
label: BODY

text: isotopes, with preferential partitioning of light Cr iso-
label: BODY

text: topes onto sorption sites. Sorption effects may be mag-
label: BODY

text: niﬁed at reaction fronts such as the leading edge of a Cr
label: BODY

text: contaminant plume in groundwater (Ellis et al. 2004).
label: BODY

text: 10.1.2 Iron (Fe)
label: BODY

text: Iron is the most abundant element on Earth and the
label: BODY

text: fourth most abundant element in the Earth’s crust. Iron
label: BODY

text: is the most widely used metal in industry, and thus is
label: BODY

text: pervasive in the environment. Iron is stable at the
label: BODY

text: Earth’s surface in two oxidation states: Fe2+ (Fe(II)),
label: BODY

text: commonly referred to as ferrous Fe, and Fe3+ (Fe(III)),
label: BODY

text: commonly referred to as ferric Fe. Fe(II) is a strong
label: BODY

text: reductant, is water-soluble, and is an important con-
label: BODY

text: stituent of Fe minerals formed under reducing condi-
label: BODY

text: tions (e.g. magnetite, siderite, pyrite). Fe(III) is only
label: BODY

text: sparingly water-soluble and is an important constitu-
label: BODY

text: ent of Fe minerals formed under oxidizing conditions
label: BODY

text: (e.g. ferrihydrite, goethite, hematite). Iron metal has
label: BODY

text: a wide variety of applications in metallurgy such as
label: BODY

text: construction of automobiles and ships, structural com-
label: BODY

text: ponents of buildings, and machinery in general. Iron
label: BODY

text: compounds such as Fe(III)-chloride and Fe(II)-sulfate
label: BODY

text: are likewise widely used in industry for a variety of
label: BODY

text: purposes. Iron plays an important role in biology and
label: BODY

text: is an essential nutrient for nearly all living organisms.
label: BODY

text: For example, Fe combines with oxygen to form hemo-
label: BODY

text: globin and myoglobin, the two main oxygen transport
label: BODY

text: proteins in vertebrates. Iron can serve as both electron
label: BODY

text: donor and electron acceptor for a wide range of micro-
label: BODY

text: organisms, and thus Fe redox reactions have the poten-
label: BODY

text: tial to support substantial microbial populations in soil
label: BODY

text: and sedimentary environments (Weber et al. 2006).
label: BODY

text: Iron has been viewed as a limiting nutrient for phyto-
label: BODY

text: plankton growth in the oceans (Martin and Fitzwater
label: BODY

text: 1988). Iron transformations and cycling processes are
label: BODY

text: critical determinants of plant, forest and agricultural
label: BODY

text: ecosystem function. Iron itself is generally non-toxic,
label: BODY

text: but dissolved Fe(II) does impart an unpleasant taste to
label: BODY

text: T.D. Bullen
label: BODY

text: water and Fe(III) staining of plumbing ﬁxtures can be
label: BODY

text: a nuisance.
label: BODY

text: Like Cr, Fe has four stable isotopes: 54Fe (5.58%),
label: BODY

text: ous rocks have a very restricted range of 56Fe/54Fe.
label: BODY

text: Presently the measured range of 56Fe/54Fe in natural
label: BODY

text: materials is ~5‰, with pyrites from Precambrian
label: BODY

text: black shales spanning this range (3.6 to +1.2‰ rela-
label: BODY

text: tive to igneous rocks; Severmann and Anbar 2009).
label: BODY

text: Both inorganic and microbially-mediated oxidation of
label: BODY

text: Fe(II) to Fe(III) and microbial reduction of Fe(III) to
label: BODY

text: Fe(II) have been shown to result in stable isotope
label: BODY

text: fractionation (Bullen et al. 2001; Balci et al. 2006;
label: BODY

text: Beard et al. 1999). Perhaps most important in this
label: BODY

text: regard is the experimentally and theoretically well-
label: BODY

text: established isotope exchange equilibrium between Fe
label: BODY

text: (II)- and Fe(III)-hexaquo complexes of ~3‰ (Johnson
label: BODY

text: et al. 2002; Anbar et al. 2005), in which the oxidized
label: BODY

text: species, Fe(III), is heavier than the reduced species,
label: BODY

text: Fe(II), as is the case for Cr. In addition, an important
label: BODY

text: role for sorption of Fe onto mineral surfaces has been
label: BODY

text: recognized, with heavy Fe species observed to popu-
label: BODY

text: late the sorption sites after equilibrium is attained
label: BODY

text: (Beard et al. 2010).
label: BODY

text: 10.1.3 Nickel (Ni)
label: BODY

text: Nickel is used in many industrial and consumer
label: BODY

text: products, including stainless steel and other metal
label: BODY

text: alloys, coins, rechargeable batteries, and electroplat-
label: BODY

text: ing. Nickel is an important trace element in ultramaﬁc
label: BODY

text: and maﬁc rocks. Nickel is stable at the Earth’s surface
label: BODY

text: in three oxidation states: primarily as Ni2+ (Ni(II)),
label: BODY

text: but also as Ni1+ (Ni(I)) and Ni3+ (Ni(III)). Nickel is
label: BODY

text: an important enzyme cofactor, for example in urease,
label: BODY

text: which assists in the hydrolysis of urea.
label: BODY

text: Nickel has ﬁve stable isotopes: 58Ni (68.1%), 60Ni
label: BODY

text: In a recent study of Ni stable isotope variations related
label: BODY

text: to methanogenesis, Cameron et al. (2009) found that
label: BODY

text: methanogens cultured in the laboratory preferentially
label: BODY

text: assimilated light Ni from the media, leaving the resi-
label: BODY

text: due enriched in heavy Ni isotopes. Fractionation of
label: BODY

text: as much as 1.6‰ for 60Ni/58Ni was observed. In
label: BODY

text: contrast, little variability was observed among mete-
label: BODY

text: orites, basalts and continental sediments, suggesting
label: BODY

text: a lithologic baseline for comparison of this potential
label: BODY

text: biomarker of methanogenesis.
label: BODY

text: 10.1.4 Copper (Cu)
label: BODY

text: Copper has a wide range of industrial applications,
label: BODY

text: including use for electrical wires, in metal alloys, in
label: BODY

text: boat paint to prevent biologic fouling, in water and gas
label: BODY

text: supply pipes, and in coins. Copper is stable at the
label: BODY

text: Earth’s surface in two oxidation states: Cu1+ (Cu(I)),
label: BODY

text: which is the common form in sulﬁde minerals such
label: BODY

text: as chalcopyrite (CuFeS2), chalcocite (Cu2S), and
label: BODY

text: enargite (Cu3AsS4); and Cu2+ (Cu(II)), which is the
label: BODY

text: common form in aqueous solution. Copper can be
label: BODY

text: toxic to animals, due in large part to its ability to
label: BODY

text: accept and donate single electrons readily as it
label: BODY

text: changes between oxidation states. This is thought to
label: BODY

text: catalyze the production of reactive radical ions leading
label: BODY

text: to the condition known as oxidative stress.
label: BODY

text: Cu has two stable isotopes: 63Cu (69.17%) and
label: BODY

text: 65Cu (30.83%). In natural materials, the measured
label: BODY

text: range of 65Cu/63Cu is approximately 9‰ for solid
label: BODY

text: samples and 3‰ for water samples (Larson et al.
label: BODY

text: 2003; Borrok et al. 2008). In one study of possible
label: BODY

text: Cu stable isotope fractionation processes, abiotic
label: BODY

text: oxidative dissolution of Cu-bearing sulﬁde minerals
label: BODY

text: resulted in the product aqueous Cu(II) being ~1.4‰
label: BODY

text: heavier in terms of the 65Cu/63Cu ratio than Cu in
label: BODY

text: chalcopyrite and ~3.0‰ heavier than Cu in chalcocite.
label: BODY

text: Involving the microbe Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans
label: BODY

text: in the dissolution process reduced the fractionation
label: BODY

text: observed in both cases (Mathur et al. 2005).
label: BODY

text: Copper isotopes are beginning to provide important
label: BODY

text: new insights into how Cu behaves in Earth’s rivers and
label: BODY

text: oceans, as well as how the isotopes may be fractio-
label: BODY

text: nated. Vance et al. (2008) reported 65Cu/63Cu ratios
label: BODY

text: for riverine water, estuarine water and particulates,
label: BODY

text: and open ocean water samples. They observed that
label: BODY

text: dissolved Cu in rivers had 65Cu/63Cu of from 0.02 to
label: BODY

text: 1.45‰ greater than that of the NIST 976 Cu standard,
label: BODY

text: and for the most part greater than that of Cu in crustal
label: BODY

text: rocks (+0.16‰ relative to NIST 976). In the estuarine
label: BODY

text: samples, 65Cu/63Cu of dissolved Cu was 0.8–1.5‰
label: BODY

text: greater than that of Cu associated with particulate
label: BODY

text: material. Vance et al. (2008) interpreted this isotopic
label: BODY

text: contrast to reﬂect isotopic partitioning of the weath-
label: BODY

text: ered pool of Cu between a light fraction adsorbed to
label: BODY

text: Stable Isotopes of Transition and Post-Transition Metals as Tracers in Environmental Studies
label: BODY

text: particulates and a heavy dissolved fraction dominated
label: BODY

text: by Cu bound to strong organic complexes, providing
label: BODY

text: a mechanism to deliver heavy dissolved Cu to the
label: BODY

text: oceans. Dissolved Cu in open ocean water samples
label: BODY

text: was even heavier than that in the river waters, suggest-
label: BODY

text: ing a continuation of the fractionation between dis-
label: BODY

text: solved and particulate Cu fractions particularly in the
label: BODY

text: surface ocean.
label: BODY

text: 10.1.5 Zinc (Zn)
label: BODY

text: The post-transition metal Zn is used in electroplating,
label: BODY

text: metal alloys, pigment in paint, agricultural fertilizers
label: BODY

text: and pesticides, galvanized rooﬁng material, and
label: BODY

text: television-screen phosphors. Zinc is stable at the
label: BODY

text: Earth’s surface in one oxidation state, Zn2+ (Zn(II)).
label: BODY

text: The large pool of Zn0 metal produced industrially is
label: BODY

text: manufactured speciﬁcally for purposes that take
label: BODY

text: advantage of its high oxidation potential relative to
label: BODY

text: other metals (e.g. as an anti-fouling and anti-corrosive
label: BODY

text: agent on the submerged portion of ship hulls and
label: BODY

text: propeller shafts). Zinc is an important enzyme
label: BODY

text: cofactor, for example in alcohol dehydrogenase in
label: BODY

text: humans, and is generally thought to be non-toxic.
label: BODY

text: Zinc has ﬁve stable isotopes: 64Zn (48.63%), 66Zn
label: BODY

text: 70Zn
label: BODY

text: (0.62%). In natural materials, the measured range of
label: BODY

text: 66Zn/64Zn is approximately 2‰ (Cloquet et al. 2008).
label: BODY

text: Mare´chal et al. (1999) published the ﬁrst high-quality
label: BODY

text: measurements of zinc and copper isotope composi-
label: BODY

text: tions in a variety of minerals and biological materials.
label: BODY

text: Since this pioneering work the ﬁeld of Zn isotope
label: BODY

text: biogeochemistry has rapidly expanded into a variety
label: BODY

text: of environmental applications. For example, Zn has a
label: BODY

text: relatively low boiling point (~910C) compared with
label: BODY

text: that of Cr or Cu, within the operating temperature
label: BODY

text: range of ore smelters. Thus Zn can evaporate from
label: BODY

text: ore during smelting, which would favor escape of light
label: BODY

text: Zn isotopes in the exhaust as demonstrated by
label: BODY

text: Mattielli et al. (2009), and retention of heavy Zn iso-
label: BODY

text: topes in the slag residue as shown by Sivry et al.
label: BODY

text: (2009). Kavner et al. (2008) demonstrated that elec-
label: BODY

text: troplated Zn, reduced to metallic state from a large
label: BODY

text: pool of aqueous Zn(II), is isotopically light compared
label: BODY

text: to the parent solution, potentially resulting in a large
label: BODY

text: pool of isotopically light electroplated Zn in the envi-
label: BODY

text: ronment. In addition, Weiss et al. (2007) demonstrated
label: BODY

text: that Zn adsorption due to complexation by organic
label: BODY

text: compounds is selective for the heavy Zn isotopes,
label: BODY

text: resulting for example in peat samples that have
label: BODY

text: heavier Zn isotope compositions than any potential
label: BODY

text: natural source. On the other hand, Borrok et al.
label: BODY

text: (2008) pointed out that Zn uptake by microorganisms
label: BODY

text: is selective for the light Zn isotopes. Thus there
label: BODY

text: are several fractionation processes for Zn that might
label: BODY

text: modify its isotope composition in the environment.
label: BODY

text: 10.1.6 Molybdenum (Mo)
label: BODY

text: Molybdenum is used in the production of high-
label: BODY

text: strength steel alloys, as pigments and catalysts, and
label: BODY

text: in a variety of high temperature applications such as
label: BODY

text: lubricants, electrical contacts and industrial motors.
label: BODY

text: Molybdenum is stable at the Earth’s surface in several
label: BODY

text: oxidation states, the most stable being Mo4+ (Mo(IV))
label: BODY

text: and Mo6+ (Mo(VI)). Molybdenum is an essential
label: BODY

text: enzyme cofactor in nearly all organisms, with particu-
label: BODY

text: lar importance for nitrogen ﬁxation, nitrate reduc-
label: BODY

text: tion and sulﬁte oxidation. Molybdenum is soluble in
label: BODY

text: strongly alkaline water such as seawater, forming
label: BODY

text: molybdates (MoO4
label: BODY

text: 2-). Molybdates bear structural
label: BODY

text: similarities to chromates, yet are weaker oxidants. In
label: BODY

text: fact, although Mo lies directly below Cr in the periodic
label: BODY

text: table, Mo compounds show more similarity to those of
label: BODY

text: tungsten (W), which lies directly below Mo in the
label: BODY

text: periodic table.
label: BODY

text: Molybdenum
label: BODY

text: has
label: BODY

text: seven
label: BODY

text: stable
label: BODY

text: isotopes:
label: BODY

text: 97Mo
label: BODY

text: 98Mo
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: 100Mo (9.63%). In natural materials, the measured
label: BODY

text: range of
label: BODY

text: 97Mo/95Mo is ~3‰, with pelagic clays
label: BODY

text: extending to 1‰ and suboxic sediment pore ﬂuids
label: BODY

text: extending to þ2‰ relative to a modeled “bulk earth”
label: BODY

text: composition as deﬁned by Mo ores (Barling et al.
label: BODY

text: 2001; Siebert et al. 2003; Anbar 2004; Arnold et al.
label: BODY

text: 2004). Molybdenum isotopes are fractionated during
label: BODY

text: adsorption to ferromanganese oxides in oxidizing
label: BODY

text: environments (Barling et al. 2001; Barling and Anbar
label: BODY

text: 2004) and precipitation of Fe-Mo-S solids in reducing
label: BODY

text: environments (Poulson et al. 2006; Neubert et al.
label: BODY

text: 2008), and the extent of fractionation differs in these
label: BODY

text: two extreme conditions. Thus Mo isotopes can provide
label: BODY

text: information about local redox conditions.
label: BODY

text: T.D. Bullen
label: BODY

text: 10.1.7 Cadmium (Cd)
label: BODY

text: The post-transition metal Cd is used primarily in
label: BODY

text: Ni-Cd batteries, metal alloys, electroplating, pigment
label: BODY

text: in paint, and electronic components. Cadmium is stable
label: BODY

text: at the Earth’s surface primarily in the Cd2+ (Cd(II))
label: BODY

text: oxidation state. Cadmium has a strong geological
label: BODY

text: afﬁnity to Zn, but unlike Zn can be toxic to humans
label: BODY

text: due to its effective substitution for calcium in bone and
label: BODY

text: its tendency to concentrate in the kidneys and liver
label: BODY

text: where it may become carcinogenic.
label: BODY

text: Cadmium has eight stable isotopes: 106Cd (1.25%),
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: 116Cd (7.49%). In terrestrial materials, the
label: BODY

text: measured range of
label: BODY

text: 114Cd/110Cd is approximately
label: BODY

text: 0.5‰; considering anthropogenically inﬂuenced mate-
label: BODY

text: rials extends that range to ~1.5‰ (Ripperger and
label: BODY

text: Rehk€amper 2007; Schmitt et al. 2009a, b; Shiel et al.
label: BODY

text: 2010). Cadmium has an even lower boiling point
label: BODY

text: (~760C) than Zn, and like Zn, Cd in ores likely
label: BODY

text: evaporates during smelting favoring escape of light
label: BODY

text: Cd isotopes in the exhaust, as recently demonstrated
label: BODY

text: by Cloquet et al. (2006a). Cadmium behaves like Zn
label: BODY

text: during electroplating (Kavner et al. 2008), potentially
label: BODY

text: resulting in a large pool of isotopically light Cd in the
label: BODY

text: environment. Although Cd is discussed in this chapter
label: BODY

text: mainly in a multi-tracer context, Rehk€amper et al.
label: BODY

text: (2011) provide a thorough discussion of the applica-
label: BODY

text: tion of Cd isotopes in environmental studies.
label: BODY

text: 10.1.8 Mercury (Hg)
label: BODY

text: The post-transition metal Hg is used in thermometers
label: BODY

text: and other scientiﬁc apparatus, amalgam for dental
label: BODY

text: restoration, Hg vapor lamps, cosmetics, and liquid
label: BODY

text: mirror telescopes. Historically, Hg has been widely
label: BODY

text: used in gold mining operations. Mercury is stable at
label: BODY

text: the Earth’s surface as soluble Hg2+ (Hg(II)) and as Hg+
label: BODY

text: (Hg(I)) in the form of monomethylmercury (CH3Hg+).
label: BODY

text: In addition, and unlike the other transition and post-
label: BODY

text: transition metals, Hg has a stable gaseous form (Hg0)
label: BODY

text: at environmental temperatures with a residence time in
label: BODY

text: the atmosphere of approximately 1 year (Schroeder
label: BODY

text: and Munthe 1998). Mercury and its compounds (e.g.
label: BODY

text: monomethylmercury (MeHg), mercuric chloride) are
label: BODY

text: extremely toxic and can be readily ingested through
label: BODY

text: inhalation or absorption through the skin and mucous
label: BODY

text: membranes.
label: BODY

text: Mercury has seven stable isotopes: 196Hg (0.15%),
label: BODY

text: Based on the compilation of existing high-precision
label: BODY

text: Hg isotope data reported by Bergquist and Blum
label: BODY

text: (2009), the measured range of 202Hg/198Hg in natural
label: BODY

text: materials resulting from mass dependent fractionation
label: BODY

text: (MDF) between coexisting Hg pools is approximately
label: BODY

text: 7‰. This is remarkable, considering that measurable
label: BODY

text: fractionation of Hg isotopes was generally thought to
label: BODY

text: be non-existent as late as the 1990s. In addition, Hg
label: BODY

text: stable isotopes exhibit considerable mass independent
label: BODY

text: fractionation (MIF), in which the odd-numbered
label: BODY

text: isotopes 199Hg and 201Hg behave differently than the
label: BODY

text: even-numbered isotopes in certain chemical reactions
label: BODY

text: such as photochemical reduction (Bergquist and Blum
label: BODY

text: 2007), leading to signiﬁcant enrichments and deple-
label: BODY

text: tions of the odd-numbered isotopes relative to the
label: BODY

text: even-numbered isotopes in environmental Hg pools.
label: BODY

text: Although Hg is included in the discussion here,
label: BODY

text: Blum (2011) provides a thorough discussion of the
label: BODY

text: theory and application of Hg isotopes in environmen-
label: BODY

text: tal studies. In his chapter, Blum (2011) points out that
label: BODY

text: most environmental applications of Hg isotopes are
label: BODY

text: concerned with either (1) interpreting the isotopic
label: BODY

text: composition of MeHg occurring in sediments and
label: BODY

text: organisms, or (2) interpreting the isotopic composition
label: BODY

text: of Hg(II) associated with sediments or deposited onto
label: BODY

text: the land surface or into a water body. In addition, the
label: BODY

text: author stresses the importance of redox reactions as
label: BODY

text: the main cause of isotope fractionation in the Hg
label: BODY

text: system and the role that the isotopes can play in
label: BODY

text: helping to increase our understanding of the chemical
label: BODY

text: bonding environments that lead to various Hg frac-
label: BODY

text: tions in sediments and other natural materials.
label: BODY

text: 10.1.9 Other Transition Metals
label: BODY

text: Potentially Having Useful
label: BODY

text: Isotopic Variability
label: BODY

text: There are several other transition metals, outlined in
label: BODY

text: blue in Fig. 10.1, that have multiple stable isotopes and
label: BODY

text: thus the potential for stable isotope variability in
label: BODY

text: Stable Isotopes of Transition and Post-Transition Metals as Tracers in Environmental Studies
label: BODY

text: nature, but which have yet to be rigorously explored in
label: BODY

text: terms of isotope systematics. Examples of these ele-
label: BODY

text: ments that would be especially useful in environmen-
label: BODY

text: tal studies are titanium (Ti), vanadium (V), silver
label: BODY

text: (Ag), tungsten (W) and rhenium (Re). For example,
label: BODY

text: as pointed out by Severman and Anbar (2009), Re
label: BODY

text: (185Re (37.4%), 187Re (62.6%); common oxidation
label: BODY

text: states Re2+, Re4+, Re6+, Re7+) is removed from solu-
label: BODY

text: tion into sediments only under anoxic or suboxic con-
label: BODY

text: ditions, making it a suitable tracer for moderately
label: BODY

text: reducing conditions. In contrast, V (50V (0.25%), 51V
label: BODY

text: (99.75%); common oxidation states V2+, V3+, V4+, V5+)
label: BODY

text: is scavenged from solution by manganese oxides and
label: BODY

text: Fe-oxyhydroxides, making it a suitable tracer for oxic
label: BODY

text: conditions. Both potential redox-tracing applications
label: BODY

text: assume that sedimentation promotes isotope fraction-
label: BODY

text: ation between sediment and residual aqueous pools of
label: BODY

text: Re or V, but such fractionation has yet to be demon-
label: BODY

text: strated.
label: BODY

text: Silver, in addition to its historic value as a precious
label: BODY

text: metal, is widely used in dentistry, photographic mate-
label: BODY

text: rials, mirrors and optics, control rods in nuclear reac-
label: BODY

text: tors, clothing (as an anti-fungal agent) and in certain
label: BODY

text: medicines. Silver has the highest electrical conductiv-
label: BODY

text: ity of any element and the highest thermal conductiv-
label: BODY

text: ity of any metal and thus is widely used in electrical
label: BODY

text: contacts and conductors. Silver is stable at the Earth’s
label: BODY

text: surface primarily in three oxidation states: Ag0 or
label: BODY

text: native silver, and Ag1+ and Ag2+, the common forms
label: BODY

text: in a wide variety of Ag-containing compounds and
label: BODY

text: minerals. Silver has two stable isotopes:
label: BODY

text: 107Ag
label: BODY

text: (51.84%) and 109Ag (48.16%). In an initial study of
label: BODY

text: Ag stable isotope variation in sediment and domestic
label: BODY

text: and industrial sludge samples, Luo et al. (2010)
label: BODY

text: reported a small but signiﬁcant range of variation in
label: BODY

text: 109Ag/107Ag of 0.1‰ that bracketed the value for their
label: BODY

text: standard. They found a different value for Ag from a
label: BODY

text: ﬁsh liver (+0.28‰ relative to their standard) that may
label: BODY

text: indicate a biological inﬂuence. However, at this stage
label: BODY

text: Ag is only beginning to be explored in terms of stable
label: BODY

text: isotope variability.
label: BODY

text: Tungsten provides an especially intriguing but
label: BODY

text: as yet untested candidate for stable isotope variation
label: BODY

text: in natural materials at the Earth’s surface. Tungsten
label: BODY

text: is used in many high-temperature applications, such as
label: BODY

text: light bulbs and welding processes, and in lubricants,
label: BODY

text: abrasives, ceramic glazes, and heavy metal alloys. The
label: BODY

text: most common oxidation state of W at the Earth’s
label: BODY

text: surface is W6+, but W exhibits all oxidation states
label: BODY

text: from W2- to W6+. Tungsten has ﬁve stable isotopes:
label: BODY

text: (30.64%) and 186W (28.43%); 180W is radioactive, but
label: BODY

text: with a half-life of 1.8  1018 years it is essentially
label: BODY

text: stable. While there is substantial literature describing
label: BODY

text: 182W variations in meteorites, there have been
label: BODY

text: essentially no published systematic studies of low-
label: BODY

text: temperature processes involving W. However, Irisawa
label: BODY

text: and Hirata (2006) reported that W isotope ratios for
label: BODY

text: Fig. 10.1 A portion of the Periodic Table of the Elements,
label: BODY

text: showing the transition and post-transition metals. Elements
label: BODY

text: with green borders are those for which signiﬁcant variability
label: BODY

text: of stable isotope composition has been observed in natural
label: BODY

text: materials. Elements with blue borders are those that have
label: BODY

text: more than one stable isotope and thus the potential to have
label: BODY

text: variability of stable isotope composition in natural materials,
label: BODY

text: but such variability has yet to be rigorously demonstrated. Ele-
label: BODY

text: ments with red borders have only one stable isotope (no stable
label: BODY

text: isotope in the case of Tc)
label: BODY

text: T.D. Bullen
label: BODY

text: sediment reference materials differed signiﬁcantly
label: BODY

text: from values for igneous rocks, hinting at the possi-
label: BODY

text: bility that low-temperature redox and/or sorption
label: BODY

text: processes may fractionate the W isotopes.
label: BODY

text: The potential for Ti to have signiﬁcant variability
label: BODY

text: of stable isotope composition in natural materials at
label: BODY

text: the Earth’s surface is probably less than that for W, V
label: BODY

text: and Re. This is due to the fact that the geochemistry of
label: BODY

text: Ti is dominated by the Ti4+ oxidation state, and Ti is
label: BODY

text: not known to play a large role in biological processes
label: BODY

text: such as enzyme stabilization. Regardless, titanium has
label: BODY

text: ﬁve stable isotopes spanning a large mass range:
label: BODY

text: and 50Ti (5.4%). If our experience with exploration of
label: BODY

text: stable isotope variability of other elements dominated
label: BODY

text: by a single oxidation state may serve as a guide, it is
label: BODY

text: not unrealistic that a thorough reconnaissance study of
label: BODY

text: Ti or other unexplored transition metal stable isotope
label: BODY

text: systematics in environmental materials (e.g. nano-
label: BODY

text: particles, pigments, electroplated steel) would reveal
label: BODY

text: unexpected surprises.
label: BODY

text: 10.2 Methodology
label: BODY

text: Although the transition and post-transition metals rep-
label: BODY

text: resent a geochemically diverse group of elements,
label: BODY

text: the details of the analytical procedures required for
label: BODY

text: measurement of their isotope compositions are quite
label: BODY

text: uniform. Once a laboratory establishes a protocol for
label: BODY

text: analysis of one of these metals, it can be relatively
label: BODY

text: straightforward to add more of the remaining metals to
label: BODY

text: the repertoire. On the other hand, transition and post-
label: BODY

text: transition metals are everywhere, in ﬁeld and labora-
label: BODY

text: tory equipment, and care must be taken to maintain
label: BODY

text: strict cleanliness during sample collection, processing
label: BODY

text: and measurement.
label: BODY

text: 10.2.1 Sampling Protocols
label: BODY

text: As a general rule, the sampling protocol for transition
label: BODY

text: or post-transition metal isotope analysis of water is
label: BODY

text: identical to that for standard dissolved cation analysis.
label: BODY

text: The sample is collected using plastic tubing for pumps
label: BODY

text: or plastic containers for dipping and placed into plastic
label: BODY

text: containers that have been rinsed several times with the
label: BODY

text: water being collected. Pre-cleaning of the plastic con-
label: BODY

text: tainers with nitric acid may be required if container
label: BODY

text: “blanks”, obtained by allowing distilled water to sit in
label: BODY

text: the container for an extended period of time, reveal
label: BODY

text: signiﬁcant metal content. The sample needs to be
label: BODY

text: ﬁltered, the pore-size of the ﬁlter being determined
label: BODY

text: by the question being asked (e.g. is there isotopic
label: BODY

text: fractionation between colloidal and non-colloidal
label: BODY

text: size fractions?). Generally an in-line ﬁlter with 0.1 mm
label: BODY

text: pore size provides sufﬁcient ﬁltration, but this may
label: BODY

text: cause retention of some of the colloidal fraction as
label: BODY

text: well (size: 1 nm–1 mm). Alternatively, the sample can
label: BODY

text: be ﬁltered after initial collection using a plastic
label: BODY

text: syringe ﬁtted with a disposable ﬁlter cartridge. Care
label: BODY

text: must be taken to prevent possible redox changes of the
label: BODY

text: redox-sensitive species in the oxic environment.
label: BODY

text: Use of an in-line ﬁlter minimizes potential formation
label: BODY

text: of Fe- and Mn-oxyhydroxides that can scavenge
label: BODY

text: the metals from solution. Additionally, collection and
label: BODY

text: ﬁltration can be carried out in a portable nitrogen-
label: BODY

text: atmosphere glove box. The sample should be acidiﬁed
label: BODY

text: with exceptionally clean nitric or hydrochloric acid, to
label: BODY

text: a pH of approximately 2.0. Additional precautions
label: BODY

text: such as wearing ultra-clean over-garments, gloves
label: BODY

text: and boots may be required, particularly when metal
label: BODY

text: concentrations are expected to be extremely small.
label: BODY

text: Knowledge of metal concentrations in the sample
label: BODY

text: prior to collection for isotope analysis is useful in
label: BODY

text: order to ensure that sufﬁcient metal is collected to
label: BODY

text: meet the requirements of the analytical technique. As
label: BODY

text: a general rule of thumb, sufﬁcient material to provide
label: BODY

text: 1–10 mg of the target metal should be collected when
label: BODY

text: possible. The amount of metal required for isotope
label: BODY

text: analysis ranges from as little as 5 ng to as much as
label: BODY

text: 1 mg, depending on factors such as ionization efﬁ-
label: BODY

text: ciency in the mass spectrometer and resolution mode
label: BODY

text: employed (see below). Moreover, knowledge of pro-
label: BODY

text: cedural blank levels is useful for deciding what kinds
label: BODY

text: of plastic tubing and containers to use and what pro-
label: BODY

text: tective measures to take. A worthwhile exercise is to
label: BODY

text: take a supply of the cleanest distilled laboratory water
label: BODY

text: available to the ﬁeld site and to treat the distilled water
label: BODY

text: as a sample, using all intended plastic tubing and
label: BODY

text: containers, ﬁlters and other collection equipment,
label: BODY

text: and techniques. One or two ﬁeld blanks should
label: BODY

text: be collected during each sampling session, and the
label: BODY

text: blank should be measured for concentration of
label: BODY

text: the metal of interest prior to investing time in sample
label: BODY

text: preparation and mass spectrometry.
label: BODY

text: Stable Isotopes of Transition and Post-Transition Metals as Tracers in Environmental Studies
label: BODY

text: Collection of solid samples such as soils, plant
label: BODY

text: tissues and landﬁll materials requires common sense
label: BODY

text: more than anything. Solid samples should be collected
label: BODY

text: into plastic bags, and care should be taken to ensure
label: BODY

text: that sampling equipment (e.g. shovels, augers, stem-
label: BODY

text: wood borers) do not contain the metal of interest.
label: BODY

text: Particular care should be taken to avoid sampling
label: BODY

text: equipment with painted surfaces as the paint is
label: BODY

text: likely to have transition or post-transition metals as
label: BODY

text: pigments.
label: BODY

text: 10.2.2 Sample Preparation
label: BODY

text: Prior to mass spectrometry, the metal of interest must
label: BODY

text: be isolated from the rest of the sample matrix and
label: BODY

text: particularly from elements that would produce iso-
label: BODY

text: baric interferences on the target masses for analysis.
label: BODY

text: For example, in preparing a sample for Cr isotope
label: BODY

text: analysis, all Ti, V and Fe must be removed, as each
label: BODY

text: of these metals has an isotope at the same mass as a
label: BODY

text: Cr isotope. Similarly, some elements form double-
label: BODY

text: charged ions in the mass spectrometer that are
label: BODY

text: detected at ½ of their mass due to the direct depen-
label: BODY

text: dence of ion ﬂight path through the magnetic sector of
label: BODY

text: the mass spectrometer on mass:charge ratio of the ion.
label: BODY

text: For example, Ba2+ ions can be formed in both multi-
label: BODY

text: collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectro-
label: BODY

text: metry (MC-ICP-MS) and thermal ionization mass
label: BODY

text: spectrometry (TIMS), the two common methods for
label: BODY

text: analysis of metal stable isotope composition. 132Ba2+
label: BODY

text: would be detected at mass 66, 134Ba2+ would be
label: BODY

text: detected at mass 67, and 136Ba2+ would be detected
label: BODY

text: at mass 68, all directly overlapping the Zn isotopes of
label: BODY

text: the same masses. Thus, a goal of the chemistry is to
label: BODY

text: produce as pure a target metal fraction as possible,
label: BODY

text: preferably if not assuredly with quantitative recovery.
label: BODY

text: Most chemical procedures for puriﬁcation of
label: BODY

text: the transition and post-transition metals involve some
label: BODY

text: form of ion exchange chromatography, making use of
label: BODY

text: different afﬁnities of the metals for the ion exchange
label: BODY

text: resins in different strengths of acid media. For exam-
label: BODY

text: ple, Wombacher et al. (2003) developed a method to
label: BODY

text: purify Cd from geological materials and meteorites.
label: BODY

text: The digested sample is dissolved in 3 M HCl and
label: BODY

text: loaded directly onto an exchange column containing
label: BODY

text: AG1-X8 strong acid anion exchange resin. The col-
label: BODY

text: umn is rinsed with set volumes of 0.5, 1, 2 and ﬁnally
label: BODY

text: 8 M HCl in order to remove the majority of matrix
label: BODY

text: elements. Following this series of rinses, all that
label: BODY

text: remains on the resin are Ag, Zn, tin (Sn) and
label: BODY

text: Cd. Additional rinsing with 8 M HCl removes the
label: BODY

text: Ag, which can be retained for isotope analysis if
label: BODY

text: desired (although quantitative recovery must be
label: BODY

text: demonstrated). The rinse solution is then changed to
label: BODY

text: a 0.5 M HNO3–0.1 M HBr mixture, which removes Zn
label: BODY

text: and some of the Sn from the column; this fraction can
label: BODY

text: be retained for further processing for Zn isotope anal-
label: BODY

text: ysis, if desired. The rinse solution is then changed to
label: BODY

text: 2 M HNO3, which removes the Cd and the remainder
label: BODY

text: of the Sn. This product solution is then taken to dry-
label: BODY

text: ness, re-dissolved in 6 M HCl and loaded onto a small
label: BODY

text: column containing a resin (TRU Spec, Eichrom
label: BODY

text: Industries) that retains the Sn but not the Cd, which
label: BODY

text: is collected in a beaker. The product solution contains
label: BODY

text: only Cd, and is ready for isotopic determination.
label: BODY

text: This example demonstrates the versatility of the ion
label: BODY

text: exchange resin method, and new element-speciﬁc
label: BODY

text: resins are continually being developed as the need
label: BODY

text: for new applications is encountered.
label: BODY

text: Procedures for chemical puriﬁcation of the other
label: BODY

text: transition and post-transition metals follow a similar
label: BODY

text: logic and most are able to achieve quantitative recov-
label: BODY

text: ery, thereby avoiding isotope fractionation on the resin
label: BODY

text: column which has been demonstrated to occur
label: BODY

text: for several elements such as Fe (Anbar et al. 2000).
label: BODY

text: References providing detailed descriptions of puriﬁca-
label: BODY

text: tion techniques for the transition and post-transition
label: BODY

text: metals discussed here include: Cr, Ellis et al. (2002;
label: BODY

text: supplementary material); Fe, Beard and Johnson
label: BODY

text: (1999); Ni, Cameron et al. (2009); Cu and Zn, Borrok
label: BODY

text: et al. (2007); Mo, Barling et al. (2001); Cd, Wombacher
label: BODY

text: et al. (2003); Ag, Luo et al. (2010); Ti, Das and Pobi
label: BODY

text: (1990); V, Pelly et al. (1970); W, Sahoo et al. (2006);
label: BODY

text: Re, Liu et al. (1998). Note that sample preparation of
label: BODY

text: Hg for isotope analysis requires an entirely different
label: BODY

text: approach, as discussed in Blum (2011).
label: BODY

text: 10.2.3 Instrumentation
label: BODY

text: As mentioned above, the stable isotope composition of
label: BODY

text: the transition and post-transition metals is measured
label: BODY

text: using either MC–ICP–MS or TIMS. A generalized
label: BODY

text: schematic of these mass spectrometers is given in
label: BODY

text: Fig. 10.2, which illustrates essential aspects of their
label: BODY

text: T.D. Bullen
label: BODY

text: function (Bullen and Eisenhauer 2009). All instru-
label: BODY

text: ments consist of three main components: ion source,
label: BODY

text: ion optics (ion acceleration, ion beam focusing,
label: BODY

text: isotope mass separation) and ion collection. Ions are
label: BODY

text: produced by thermal processes in the source region: in
label: BODY

text: MC-ICP-MS, the sample is injected into the source
label: BODY

text: region either as a nebulized liquid aerosol or as ablated
label: BODY

text: solid particulate in a gaseous stream which passes
label: BODY

text: through a high-temperature plasma (up to 10,000K;
label: BODY

text: see photo insert in Fig. 10.2) at near-atmospheric
label: BODY

text: pressure. At this high temperature, atoms of the sam-
label: BODY

text: ple material are very efﬁciently ionized. In TIMS, the
label: BODY

text: sample is deposited on a wire ﬁlament (see photo insert
label: BODY

text: in Fig. 10.2), placed in a high vacuum (~10-8 torr), and
label: BODY

text: the ﬁlament is heated to the temperature required for
label: BODY

text: ion production of the particular element (typically
label: BODY

text: 800–1,700C). The ions produced in either instrument
label: BODY

text: then enter the optics region, where they are accelerated
label: BODY

text: through a large potential (up to 10 kV) and focused
label: BODY

text: electronically to create a discrete ion beam. In MC-
label: BODY

text: ICP-MS, the vacuum must be substantially improved
label: BODY

text: over this short optics region via efﬁcient mechanical
label: BODY

text: and electrical “ion getter” vacuum pumps. Beyond the
label: BODY

text: ion optics region, an exceptional vacuum (~10-8 torr)
label: BODY

text: must be maintained in both instruments.
label: BODY

text: The accelerated and focused ion beam then passes
label: BODY

text: through a slit into the ﬂight tube where the different
label: BODY

text: isotopes of the element are dispersed by mass using
label: BODY

text: an electromagnet. The width of the slit determines the
label: BODY

text: ability of the mass spectrometer to partially resolve
label: BODY

text: sample ions and extraneous molecules of nearly simi-
label: BODY

text: lar mass (“isobaric interferences”). For example, since
label: BODY

text: the plasma in ICP-source instruments is predomi-
label: BODY

text: nantly composed of Ar, a narrow slit must be used to
label: BODY

text: resolve 56Fe from 40Ar16O. In TIMS instruments, 56Fe
label: BODY

text: must be resolved from organic molecules with mass
label: BODY

text: ~56 atomic mass units. In general, a narrower slit
label: BODY

text: provides greater resolving power but reduced signal
label: BODY

text: intensity.
label: BODY

text: The fundamental power of MC-ICP-MS and TIMS
label: BODY

text: instruments to disperse the isotopes of an element rests
label: BODY

text: in the ability of the magnet to differentially divert the
label: BODY

text: ﬂight paths of the various isotopes according to their
label: BODY

text: individual energies. The ion ﬂight paths are bent along
label: BODY

text: the axis of the ﬂight tube depending on the ratio of ion
label: BODY

text: mass to charge: light ions are bent more (green path in
label: BODY

text: diagram), heavy ions are bent less (red path in dia-
label: BODY

text: gram). For any particular isotope, a restricted range of
label: BODY

text: ion energies leaving the magnetic sector is required to
label: BODY

text: create a concentrated, ﬂat-topped signal that is ideal
label: BODY

text: Fig. 10.2 Generalized
label: BODY

text: schematic of the important
label: BODY

text: aspects of multi-collector mass
label: BODY

text: spectrometers used for
label: BODY

text: determination of metal stable
label: BODY

text: isotope compositions. Key
label: BODY

text: features are discussed in the text.
label: BODY

text: Modiﬁed after Bullen and
label: BODY

text: Eisenhauer (2009)
label: BODY

text: Stable Isotopes of Transition and Post-Transition Metals as Tracers in Environmental Studies
label: BODY

text: for detection and measurement. In TIMS, ions of a
label: BODY

text: particular isotope produced at the source ﬁlament are
label: BODY

text: essentially mono-energetic, and once the ion beam is
label: BODY

text: focused in the source region mass (i.e. energy) disper-
label: BODY

text: sion can be effectively achieved in the magnetic sec-
label: BODY

text: tor. In contrast, in MC-ICP-MS ions of a particular
label: BODY

text: isotope leave the source region having a fairly wide
label: BODY

text: energy distribution due to numerous processes occur-
label: BODY

text: ring in the source region. Thus in most MC-ICP-MS
label: BODY

text: instruments, the poly-energetic ion beam must ﬁrst
label: BODY

text: pass
label: BODY

text: through
label: BODY

text: electrostatic
label: BODY

text: discriminator
label: BODY

text: (not
label: BODY

text: shown) which disperses the ion beam in exactly the
label: BODY

text: opposite sense to that which follows in the magnetic
label: BODY

text: sector. As a result of exacting electromechanical
label: BODY

text: design, the ion beam that ultimately passes out of the
label: BODY

text: magnetic sector has a balanced and much smaller
label: BODY

text: energy spread that allows the ﬂat-topped signal to
label: BODY

text: develop. In a few MC-ICP-MS instruments, the ion
label: BODY

text: beam ﬁrst passes through a “collision cell” containing
label: BODY

text: molecules of a gas such as Ar where collisions of the
label: BODY

text: metal ions with the gas molecules substantially reduce
label: BODY

text: the kinetic energies of those ions, which can then
label: BODY

text: be reaccelerated in a nearly mono-energetic condition
label: BODY

text: for passage through the magnetic ﬁeld as in TIMS.
label: BODY

text: Ion detection collectors are conﬁgured to perfectly
label: BODY

text: intersect the resulting ﬂight paths of the component
label: BODY

text: isotope ion beams of the element. In some instruments,
label: BODY

text: collectors can be moved perpendicularly to the ion
label: BODY

text: paths until desired coincidence is achieved for a
label: BODY

text: particular element. In other instruments, the collector
label: BODY

text: positions are ﬁxed and the trajectories of the ion beams
label: BODY

text: themselves are adjusted along the ﬁnal section of the
label: BODY

text: ﬂight tube by further electronic focusing in order to
label: BODY

text: achieve coincidence. Collectors are either Faraday
label: BODY

text: cages, credit-card sized, thin rectangular boxes open
label: BODY

text: on one narrow end to receive and trap ions on the
label: BODY

text: internal surfaces resulting in a measurable total ion
label: BODY

text: current on the internal surfaces, or ion counters that
label: BODY

text: record individual ion collisions with the counter sur-
label: BODY

text: faces. Faraday cages may have slits positioned along
label: BODY

text: the ion ﬂight path prior to the point of ion entry into
label: BODY

text: the cage in order to better shape the ion beam for
label: BODY

text: optimum signal detection. Channel-speciﬁc total ion
label: BODY

text: currents detected over a certain period of time are then
label: BODY

text: processed through a series of electronic conversions
label: BODY

text: into signals that can be interpreted by computer soft-
label: BODY

text: ware as relative isotope abundances for the element.
label: BODY

text: Each instrument has its advantages in certain
label: BODY

text: applications, but as a general rule the stable isotope
label: BODY

text: composition of all the transition and post-transition
label: BODY

text: metals discussed in this chapter can be most efﬁciently
label: BODY

text: determined using MC-ICP-MS. The high ionization
label: BODY

text: efﬁciency of the plasma source used to generate ions
label: BODY

text: in MC-ICP-MS compared to that of the metal ﬁlament
label: BODY

text: source used in TIMS results in improved isotope mea-
label: BODY

text: surement of very small quantities (i.e. tens of nano-
label: BODY

text: grams) of elements with high ionization potentials,
label: BODY

text: such as Zn (e.g. Chen et al. 2008), Mo (e.g. Barling
label: BODY

text: and Anbar 2004), and Hg (e.g. Blum and Bergquist
label: BODY

text: 2007). In addition, MC-ICP-MS instruments typically
label: BODY

text: have the capability to sufﬁciently resolve measureable
label: BODY

text: portions of metal ion beams from “isobaric” poly-
label: BODY

text: atomic interfering species having nearly the same
label: BODY

text: mass (e.g.
label: BODY

text: 56Fe vs.
label: BODY

text: 40Ar16O generated in the Ar
label: BODY

text: plasma). Some interfering species, primarily oxides,
label: BODY

text: can also be removed from the ion stream to a large
label: BODY

text: extent by desolvating the sample prior to introduction
label: BODY

text: to the plasma. Alternatively, in some instruments
label: BODY

text: polyatomic molecules can be disaggregated in the
label: BODY

text: collision cell apparatus described above due to colli-
label: BODY

text: sions of the molecules with atoms of the gas supplied
label: BODY

text: to the cell. In MC-IPC-MS, uncertainty due to signal
label: BODY

text: noise resulting from the inherent instability of the
label: BODY

text: plasma source is eliminated by measuring all ion
label: BODY

text: beams simultaneously with the multicollector array.
label: BODY

text: An additional strength of MC-ICP-MS is that samples
label: BODY

text: can be introduced using laser ablation equipment, in
label: BODY

text: which layers of atoms are sputtered off the surface of
label: BODY

text: a solid material and transported by a gas stream to
label: BODY

text: the plasma for ionization. Excellent references on the
label: BODY

text: general topic of isotope analysis by MC-ICP-MS are
label: BODY

text: Albare`de and Beard (2004), Rehk€amper et al. (2004)
label: BODY

text: and Wieser and Schwieters (2005).
label: BODY

text: On the other hand, TIMS has been used for more
label: BODY

text: than 50 years and has long been the workhorse for
label: BODY

text: metal isotope research. TIMS provided much of the
label: BODY

text: data on transition and post-transition metal stable iso-
label: BODY

text: tope systematics prior to the proliferation of MC-ICP-
label: BODY

text: MS in research labs and continues to provide excellent
label: BODY

text: isotope measurements for more readily ionized ele-
label: BODY

text: ments such as Cr (e.g. Ellis et al. 2002) and Fe (Bullen
label: BODY

text: and Amundson 2010) and even for elements that are
label: BODY

text: difﬁcult to ionize such as Cd (Schmitt et al. 2009a, b).
label: BODY

text: TIMS is less affected by isobaric interferences than
label: BODY

text: MC–ICP–MS because there is no need for the Ar gas
label: BODY

text: and because the sample is ionized under high vacuum
label: BODY

text: rather than in an aqueous solution or gas stream
label: BODY

text: at atmospheric pressure. TIMS likewise beneﬁts from
label: BODY

text: T.D. Bullen
label: BODY

text: simultaneous
label: BODY

text: multicollector
label: BODY

text: ion
label: BODY

text: beam
label: BODY

text: detection
label: BODY

text: (Fantle and Bullen 2009). Typical external precision
label: BODY

text: (i.e. comparison of total procedural replicates for nat-
label: BODY

text: ural samples) is at the 0.1‰ level for both TIMS and
label: BODY

text: MC–ICP–MS. A disadvantage of both instruments is a
label: BODY

text: sizable footprint in the laboratory and high costs for
label: BODY

text: purchase and maintenance.
label: BODY

text: 10.2.4 Data: Acquisition, Reduction,
label: BODY

text: Accuracy, and Standard
label: BODY

text: Reference Materials
label: BODY

text: Isotope fractionation of the ion beam produced in both
label: BODY

text: TIMS and MC-ICP-MS, which is an unavoidable char-
label: BODY

text: acteristic of both analytical platforms, means that the
label: BODY

text: relative proportion of isotopes of an element reaching
label: BODY

text: the detectors in the mass spectrometer is not identical
label: BODY

text: to that of the sample. This instrument-induced frac-
label: BODY

text: tionation, or “mass bias”, is often larger than the
label: BODY

text: isotopic variation between samples. In MC-IPC-MS,
label: BODY

text: light ions of any element are preferentially discrimi-
label: BODY

text: nated against and removed from the ion stream at
label: BODY

text: the sampling cones situated just beyond the plasma
label: BODY

text: source, resulting in relatively heavy raw measured
label: BODY

text: ratios that tend to stay very constant over the course
label: BODY

text: of a measurement. In TIMS, light ions of any element
label: BODY

text: are preferentially ionized off the ﬁlament surface,
label: BODY

text: causing the raw measured ratio to be light at the outset
label: BODY

text: and progressively heavier over the course of a mea-
label: BODY

text: surement. Thus it is essential to provide some means to
label: BODY

text: correct for isotope discrimination so that measured
label: BODY

text: isotope compositions of samples can be compared to
label: BODY

text: those of standards and other samples.
label: BODY

text: The classic approach to correct for isotope discrim-
label: BODY

text: ination in TIMS is referred to as the double spike
label: BODY

text: technique. An excellent treatment of the theoretical
label: BODY

text: aspects of the double spike technique is given by
label: BODY

text: Johnson and Beard (1999), and a practical overview
label: BODY

text: of the technique is provided by Rudge et al. (2009).
label: BODY

text: This technique requires that the element have at least
label: BODY

text: four naturally-occurring isotopes, two that can be used
label: BODY

text: as isotopes for the double spike and two that can be
label: BODY

text: used to calculate a ratio that provides information
label: BODY

text: on the relative natural isotope composition of a sam-
label: BODY

text: ple. The double spike is a mixture of two typically
label: BODY

text: minor isotopes of the element that have each been
label: BODY

text: industrially enriched in their proportion relative to
label: BODY

text: the other isotopes. There are now several commercial
label: BODY

text: suppliers of highly enriched (i.e. typically >90% pure)
label: BODY

text: stable isotopes of most multi-isotopic elements, and
label: BODY

text: thus it is relatively straightforward to create a double
label: BODY

text: spike using any combination of two isotopes of an
label: BODY

text: element. The double spike mixture, which has been
label: BODY

text: carefully characterized for isotope composition and
label: BODY

text: concentration, is added to a sample prior to analysis
label: BODY

text: thus imparting an unnatural isotope composition to the
label: BODY

text: sample-double spike mixture. Following analysis,
label: BODY

text: the measured ratio of the two isotopes used to create
label: BODY

text: the double spike can be compared to the known, care-
label: BODY

text: fully characterized value to obtain a “mass bias factor”
label: BODY

text: that quantiﬁes isotope fractionation that has occurred
label: BODY

text: during analysis. The measured isotope composition of
label: BODY

text: the sample-double spike mixture can then be corrected
label: BODY

text: based on this mass bias factor, and the double spike
label: BODY

text: component of the mixture can be mathematically
label: BODY

text: subtracted from the fractionation-corrected composi-
label: BODY

text: tion to reveal the natural ratios of the two or more
label: BODY

text: isotopes not used for the double spike as the residual.
label: BODY

text: For example, the 53Cr/52Cr natural isotope ratio of
label: BODY

text: a sample can be determined using a double spike
label: BODY

text: consisting of a mixture of nearly pure 50Cr and 54Cr,
label: BODY

text: the two minor isotopes of Cr. Of the elements dis-
label: BODY

text: cussed here, Cr, Fe, Ni, Zn, Cd, Mo, Hg, Ti, and W
label: BODY

text: are suitable for analysis by the double spike technique
label: BODY

text: while Ag, Re and V are not. An important advantage
label: BODY

text: of the double spike technique is that the double
label: BODY

text: spike solution can be added to the sample prior to puri-
label: BODY

text: ﬁcation chemistry, and thus, without any additional
label: BODY

text: effort, can be used to correct for isotope fractionation
label: BODY

text: that might occur during chemical puriﬁcation prior to
label: BODY

text: analysis (e.g. due to non-quantitative recovery of the
label: BODY

text: metal from the resin).
label: BODY

text: The nature of MC-ICP-MS allows application of
label: BODY

text: two additional techniques for correction of isotope
label: BODY

text: discrimination in the instrument during analysis,
label: BODY

text: standard-sample-standard bracketing and internal
label: BODY

text: standardization. As the name implies, in standard-
label: BODY

text: sample-standard bracketing a standard solution is
label: BODY

text: analyzed directly before and after a sample, and the
label: BODY

text: interpolated isotope ratio of the standard at the time of
label: BODY

text: the sample analysis is taken as the reference value.
label: BODY

text: This is an incredibly straightforward approach, but
label: BODY

text: assumes that the sample and standard behave similarly
label: BODY

text: in the plasma (e.g. have identical matrices). With
label: BODY

text: internal standardization, an element with a known
label: BODY

text: Stable Isotopes of Transition and Post-Transition Metals as Tracers in Environmental Studies
label: BODY

text: isotope composition and similar fractionation behav-
label: BODY

text: ior to the element being analyzed is added to the
label: BODY

text: sample solution prior to aspiration into the plasma
label: BODY

text: (e.g. Zr as an internal standard for Mo isotope analysis,
label: BODY

text: Cu as an internal standard for Fe or Zn isotope analy-
label: BODY

text: sis). The isotope ratio measured for the internal stan-
label: BODY

text: dard can be compared to its known value to quantify
label: BODY

text: machine-induced fractionation and a correction can
label: BODY

text: then be applied to the isotope ratio of the target ele-
label: BODY

text: ment on a scan by scan basis. Using internal standar-
label: BODY

text: dization, a plot of the measured isotope ratios of the
label: BODY

text: target element vs. those of the internal standard ele-
label: BODY

text: ment typically deﬁnes a mass dependent fractionation
label: BODY

text: relationship that provides the basis for the correction
label: BODY

text: (Longerich et al. (1987); Mare´chal et al. (1999).
label: BODY

text: The power of the standard-sample-standard brack-
label: BODY

text: eting and internal standardization techniques is that
label: BODY

text: they can be used for isotopic analysis of any element
label: BODY

text: having two or more isotopes. On the other hand, the
label: BODY

text: double spike technique required for TIMS stable iso-
label: BODY

text: tope analysis can likewise be used for MC-ICP-MS
label: BODY

text: isotope analysis of elements having four or more iso-
label: BODY

text: topes, and is in essence a special case of internal
label: BODY

text: standardization. The advantage of using a double
label: BODY

text: spike for MC-ICP-MS analysis is that quantitative
label: BODY

text: yield during sample puriﬁcation is not required as it
label: BODY

text: is for standard-sample-standard bracketing and inter-
label: BODY

text: nal standardization approaches (Siebert et al. 2001).
label: BODY

text: Differences in transition and post-transition metal
label: BODY

text: stable isotope composition between materials tend
label: BODY

text: to be small, a few parts per thousand at most, so
label: BODY

text: that differences in absolute isotope ratio are difﬁcult
label: BODY

text: to conceptualize. For example, say that the 53Cr/52Cr
label: BODY

text: ratio determined by TIMS for a native groundwater
label: BODY

text: sample is 0.114000, while the value for the Cr isotope
label: BODY

text: standard is 0.113392. To better visualize this small
label: BODY

text: difference, most researchers in the ﬁeld have adopted
label: BODY

text: the delta notation used for gas isotope ratio compari-
label: BODY

text: son so that ratios can be compared on a per mil (‰)
label: BODY

text: basis. Using the Cr example:
label: BODY

text: d53=52Cr¼1000ð53Cr=52Crgroundwater
label: BODY

text: 53Cr=52CrstandardÞ=53Cr=ð52CrstandardÞ
label: BODY

text: d values are preceded by a plus or minus sign to
label: BODY

text: denote ratios that are, respectively, heavier or lighter
label: BODY

text: than the reference material, which in this case is NIST
label: BODY

text: 979 Cr metal. There are two important variants of the d
label: BODY

text: notation: (1) DA-B may be used to represent the differ-
label: BODY

text: ence in d values between two samples, A and B; and
label: BODY

text: (2) workers may use the e notation, equal to 10 times
label: BODY

text: d, or parts per 10,000, in cases where differences in
label: BODY

text: isotope composition between samples are extremely
label: BODY

text: small. Caution is advised as there are additional uses
label: BODY

text: of both D and e in isotope science terminology, and
label: BODY

text: some researchers report isotope ratio variations on a
label: BODY

text: per atomic mass unit basis.
label: BODY

text: Standard reference materials (SRM) provide the
label: BODY

text: basis for inter- and intra-laboratory comparison of
label: BODY

text: isotope ratio measurements. While the mass spectro-
label: BODY

text: meters used in different laboratories might produce
label: BODY

text: different absolute values for an SRM, the ratios
label: BODY

text: obtained on samples are comparable through use of
label: BODY

text: the delta scale described above, calculated relative to
label: BODY

text: the SRM. Most standards used in metal stable isotope
label: BODY

text: research are supplied by two sources: the Institute
label: BODY

text: for Reference Materials and Measurements (IRMM,
label: BODY

text: Belgium) and the National Institute for Standards and
label: BODY

text: Technology (NIST, USA). Both organizations have
label: BODY

text: gone to great lengths to produce large quantities of
label: BODY

text: metal isotope SRM, which have been rigorously
label: BODY

text: assessed through round-robin analyses at a number of
label: BODY

text: isotope laboratories. A good SRM must (1) be in
label: BODY

text: abundant supply and available for distribution, (2) be
label: BODY

text: homogeneous in isotopic composition across the supply,
label: BODY

text: (3) have an isotopic composition similar to or border-
label: BODY

text: ing the range to be measured in samples, and (4) have
label: BODY

text: an agreed-upon value. Ideally, for a given metal it
label: BODY

text: is preferable to have at least two well-characterized
label: BODY

text: SRM that bracket the range of isotope ratios antici-
label: BODY

text: pated in samples. This is rarely the case, and thus most
label: BODY

text: researchers rely on a single SRM that is used widely
label: BODY

text: by other laboratories, together with routinely analyzed
label: BODY

text: internal standards used to monitor consistency of lab-
label: BODY

text: oratory processing and mass spectrometer function.
label: BODY

text: An important point is that all isotope research should
label: BODY

text: be conducted using widely available SRM in order to
label: BODY

text: allow other laboratories to make a check of accuracy.
label: BODY

text: Commonly used SRM include: Cr, NIST 979; Fe,
label: BODY

text: IRMM-014; Ni, NIST 986; Cu, NIST 976; Zn, JMC
label: BODY

text: (Johnson Matthey Corporation) 3-0749-L and IRMM-
label: BODY

text: 3702; Mo, NIST 3134 (proposed; presently there is no
label: BODY

text: internationally accepted SRM (Wen et al. 2010), but
label: BODY

text: acceptance by the isotope community requires a
label: BODY

text: period of inter-laboratory comparison to validate the
label: BODY

text: T.D. Bullen
label: BODY

text: choice); Cd, JMC lot 502552A and NIST 3108;
label: BODY

text: Ag, NIST 978a. Note that there are currently no inter-
label: BODY

text: nationally accepted or proposed SRM for Ti, V, W or
label: BODY

text: Re isotope analysis.
label: BODY

text: IRMM and NIST typically supply an SRM for
label: BODY

text: metal stable isotope analysis in the form of a puriﬁed
label: BODY

text: metal or salt, both of which are easy to dissolve and
label: BODY

text: use routinely. However, some researchers choose
label: BODY

text: to use natural samples as standards, provided those
label: BODY

text: samples meet the criteria listed above. The advan-
label: BODY

text: tage of using a natural material as an SRM is that it
label: BODY

text: must follow the same chemical puriﬁcation steps as
label: BODY

text: samples, thus assuring integrity of the chemical pro-
label: BODY

text: cedures. For some metals, there are both natural and
label: BODY

text: synthetic SRM. For Fe stable isotope research, for
label: BODY

text: example, there are two widely available SRM: speciﬁc
label: BODY

text: basalts and other igneous rocks, which have been
label: BODY

text: shown to have uniform isotope composition (Beard
label: BODY

text: et al. 2003), and IRMM-014, a synthetic iron standard.
label: BODY

text: The isotope composition of IRMM-014 is now gener-
label: BODY

text: ally considered to be the zero point for the delta scale;
label: BODY

text: on this basis, igneous rocks have on average a d56/54Fe
label: BODY

text: value of þ0.09‰. Unfortunately, Fe lacks SRM
label: BODY

text: having isotope compositions at the light and heavy
label: BODY

text: extremes of the natural spectrum.
label: BODY

text: 10.3 Metal Stable Isotope Fractionation
label: BODY

text: Processes
label: BODY

text: Isotope fractionation is a set of processes which can
label: BODY

text: divide an isotopically homogeneous pool of an ele-
label: BODY

text: ment into multiple fractions that have different com-
label: BODY

text: plementary isotope compositions. For a given element,
label: BODY

text: observed fractionation may be either mass dependent,
label: BODY

text: scaling approximately as the mass difference between
label: BODY

text: isotope pairs, or mass independent, where one isotope
label: BODY

text: behaves non-systematically with respect to the others.
label: BODY

text: By far, most of the stable isotope variability of the
label: BODY

text: transition and post-transition metals observed to date
label: BODY

text: has resulted from mass dependent processes.
label: BODY

text: There are two main categories of isotope frac-
label: BODY

text: tionation processes that affect the transition and
label: BODY

text: post-transition metals, kinetic isotope effects and equi-
label: BODY

text: librium isotope exchange. Kinetic isotope effects
label: BODY

text: result from uni-directional physical and chemical
label: BODY

text: reactions, during which the light isotope is always
label: BODY

text: favored in the product phase. Examples of processes
label: BODY

text: resulting in kinetic isotope effects are evaporation,
label: BODY

text: where light isotopes of metals such as Zn and Cd
label: BODY

text: escape more efﬁciently at the liquid-air interface than
label: BODY

text: heavy isotopes (e.g. Cloquet et al. 2006a, b), electro-
label: BODY

text: plating, where light isotopes of metals from the plating
label: BODY

text: bath are preferentially deposited onto a metal substrate
label: BODY

text: (Kavner et al. 2008), and diffusion (Richter et al.
label: BODY

text: 2009). A special class of kinetic isotope effects arises
label: BODY

text: for elements having differences in speciﬁc isotope
label: BODY

text: reaction rates, for example where the odd-numbered
label: BODY

text: isotopes of Hg behave non-systematically with respect
label: BODY

text: to the even-numbered isotopes (Bergquist and Blum
label: BODY

text: 2009; Blum 2011). Isotope equilibrium results from
label: BODY

text: protracted exchange between reaction products and
label: BODY

text: reactants, and at equilibrium the products may be
label: BODY

text: either lighter or heavier than the reactants depending
label: BODY

text: on factors such as metal ion coordination, packing
label: BODY

text: density and bond strength. Examples of processes
label: BODY

text: resulting in isotope equilibrium are the partitioning
label: BODY

text: of relatively heavy Fe into [Fe(III)(H2O)6](aq)
label: BODY

text: 3+ com-
label: BODY

text: pared to Fe in coexisting [Fe(II)(H2O)6](aq)
label: BODY

text: 2+ (Johnson
label: BODY

text: et al. 2002; Welch et al. 2003), and the exchange of Fe
label: BODY

text: between hematite and [Fe(III)(H2O)6](aq)
label: BODY

text: 3+ leading to
label: BODY

text: identical Fe isotope compositions of these two phases
label: BODY

text: (i.e. no isotope fractionation). This latter example is
label: BODY

text: interesting in that hematite formed initially in synthe-
label: BODY

text: sis experiments has light Fe relative to coexisting
label: BODY

text: [Fe(III)(H2O)6](aq)
label: BODY

text: 3+ due to kinetic isotope effects
label: BODY

text: that are subsequently reversed (Skulan et al. 2002).
label: BODY

text: Note that isotope equilibrium between liquid and
label: BODY

text: vapor is likewise possible, as in the case of Hg
label: BODY

text: (Estrade et al. 2009). Excellent discussions of the
label: BODY

text: topic of kinetic and equilibrium isotope fractionation,
label: BODY

text: with examples pertinent to environmental studies, are
label: BODY

text: provided by Clark and Fritz (1997) and Kendall and
label: BODY

text: McDonnell (1998).
label: BODY

text: Redox reactions, whether strictly inorganic or
label: BODY

text: microbially mediated, consistently result in signiﬁcant
label: BODY

text: metal stable isotope fractionation, and the reduced
label: BODY

text: species of the metal redox pair is generally isotopi-
label: BODY

text: cally lighter than the oxidized species. Thus, deter-
label: BODY

text: mination of the isotope composition of redox-sensitive
label: BODY

text: metals has proven useful for understanding redox
label: BODY

text: dynamics in paleo- and present-day environmental
label: BODY

text: systems (Severmann and Anbar 2009; Bergquist and
label: BODY

text: Blum 2009; Bullen and Walczyk 2009). On the other
label: BODY

text: hand, the stable isotope composition of metals which
label: BODY

text: occur naturally in only one redox state (e.g. Cd, Zn)
label: BODY

text: Stable Isotopes of Transition and Post-Transition Metals as Tracers in Environmental Studies
label: BODY

text: but which may fractionate during complexation with
label: BODY

text: redox-sensitive species such as sulfur (Schauble 2003)
label: BODY

text: or with organic matter (Weiss et al. 2007) can likewise
label: BODY

text: be indicative of redox conditions.
label: BODY

text: Sorption of metals onto the surfaces of minerals in
label: BODY

text: sediments and soils is an environmentally important
label: BODY

text: process that can help to moderate aqueous concentra-
label: BODY

text: tions of those metals and aid in metal contaminant
label: BODY

text: remediation. Isotope fractionation associated with
label: BODY

text: sorption has been recognized for several of the transi-
label: BODY

text: tion and post-transition metals, but is highly element
label: BODY

text: speciﬁc. For example, sorption of isotopically light
label: BODY

text: Mo onto ferromanganese oxides in the oxic oceans is
label: BODY

text: viewed as having been an important isotope fraction-
label: BODY

text: ation process for Mo over much of Earth history
label: BODY

text: (Wasylenki et al. 2008). In contrast, sorbed Fe(II)
label: BODY

text: on goethite was found to be isotopically heavy com-
label: BODY

text: pared to [Fe(II)(H2O)6](aq)
label: BODY

text: 3+ in a series of carefully
label: BODY

text: conducted equilibrium isotope exchange experiments
label: BODY
