text: reported by Beard et al. (2010). In the case of Cr,
label: BODY

text: only a negligible isotope fractionation was observed
label: BODY

text: between sorbed and aqueous CrO4
label: BODY

text: 2- and HCr2O7
label: BODY

text: when either g-Al2O3 or goethite was used as the sorp-
label: BODY

text: tion substrate (Ellis et al. 2004).
label: BODY

text: Coordination environment of the metals in liquids
label: BODY

text: and solids is an additional important determinant of
label: BODY

text: stable isotope fractionation. In general, for a given
label: BODY

text: system chemistry, higher coordination favors the ligh-
label: BODY

text: ter isotopes. Using the system Fe-O as an example, Fe
label: BODY

text: in hematite (Fe2O3) is in octahedral coordination while
label: BODY

text: Fe in magnetite (Fe3O4) is in both octahedral and
label: BODY

text: tetrahedral coordination within their respective oxy-
label: BODY

text: gen framework. The result is a higher average coordi-
label: BODY

text: nation number for Fe in hematite than for Fe in
label: BODY

text: magnetite. As expected, when the two phases coexist
label: BODY

text: at or near equilibrium, Fe in hematite is isotopically
label: BODY

text: lighter than Fe in magnetite by approximately 3‰, as
label: BODY

text: has been reported for coexisting magnetite-hematite
label: BODY

text: pairs in banded iron formations (Johnson et al. 2003).
label: BODY

text: The difference in metal ion coordination environment
label: BODY

text: in coexisting solid-liquid pairs is likewise an impor-
label: BODY

text: tant determinant of stable isotope fractionation. For
label: BODY

text: example, theoretical calculations of equilibrium iso-
label: BODY

text: tope fractionation predict that aqueous Fe(II), which is
label: BODY

text: in octahedral coordination within a “hexaquo” inner
label: BODY

text: hydration sphere ([Fe(II)(H2O)6](aq)
label: BODY

text: 2+), should be
label: BODY

text: heavier than Fe(II) in coexisting siderite (FeCO3), in
label: BODY

text: which the Fe(II) is in more open octahedral coordina-
label: BODY

text: tion with oxygen of the carbonate groups (Polyakov
label: BODY

text: and Mineev 2000; Schauble 2004). Siderite synthesis
label: BODY

text: experiments conﬁrm the sense of this theoretical frac-
label: BODY

text: tionation, but observed magnitudes are less than those
label: BODY

text: predicted by theory (Wiesli et al. 2004). Gaining a
label: BODY

text: better understanding of aqueous metal coordination
label: BODY

text: environments and the implications for stable isotope
label: BODY

text: fractionation is one of the major challenges facing the
label: BODY

text: ﬁeld.
label: BODY

text: 10.4 Applications of Metal Isotopes
label: BODY

text: to Environmental Studies
label: BODY

text: The transition and post-transition metals are subject to
label: BODY

text: numerous potential isotope fractionation processes
label: BODY

text: over a wide range of environmental conditions, and
label: BODY

text: thus their isotope compositions may provide a unique
label: BODY

text: record of those processes that can be used to under-
label: BODY

text: stand present-day and paleo-environmental systems.
label: BODY

text: In this section, several examples are given that illus-
label: BODY

text: trate the spectrum of environmental issues that can be
label: BODY

text: addressed using these novel stable isotope tracers as
label: BODY

text: process recorders. These include using the isotopes to
label: BODY

text: trace metal contaminants, to identify metal redox pro-
label: BODY

text: cesses, to assess plant nutrition cycles and understand
label: BODY

text: processes within plants, and to serve as biomarkers.
label: BODY

text: Although familiarity with the general topic of stable
label: BODY

text: isotope biogeochemistry will help the reader to appre-
label: BODY

text: ciate the details of the following examples, the intro-
label: BODY

text: ductory material and references in this and other
label: BODY

text: chapters of this book should help those not familiar
label: BODY

text: with the ﬁeld to better understand why the isotopes are
label: BODY

text: useful and how they work in these speciﬁc cases.
label: BODY

text: 10.4.1 Tracing Metal Contaminant
label: BODY

text: Sources and Sinks
label: BODY

text: The ability of isotope signatures to trace the sources of
label: BODY

text: and processes affecting metal contaminants in ground-
label: BODY

text: water and the atmosphere appears to be receiving the
label: BODY

text: most attention from research groups focused on envi-
label: BODY

text: ronmental applications of transition and post-transition
label: BODY

text: metal stable isotopes. Of metal contaminants in
label: BODY

text: groundwater, Cr(VI) is arguably the best understood
label: BODY

text: in terms of isotope systematics based on laboratory
label: BODY

text: T.D. Bullen
label: BODY

text: experiments, and Cr stable isotopes have been used to
label: BODY

text: study the fate of toxic Cr contamination at numerous
label: BODY

text: ﬁeld sites. Of the potential metal contaminants in the
label: BODY

text: atmosphere, the most progress has been made in
label: BODY

text: understanding Hg sources and sinks as discussed by
label: BODY

text: Blum (2011), but Zn, Cd and Cr are likewise receiving
label: BODY

text: considerable attention and are discussed here.
label: BODY

text: 10.4.1.1 Tracing Sources of Chromium
label: BODY

text: in Groundwater
label: BODY

text: As described above in the overview of Cr, reduction of
label: BODY

text: Cr(VI) to Cr(III) is accompanied by a large isotope
label: BODY

text: fractionation. Thus, Cr stable isotopes should be use-
label: BODY

text: ful for monitoring Cr(VI) reduction in a contaminant
label: BODY

text: plume, for distinguishing between Cr(VI) reduction
label: BODY

text: and advective mixing with Cr-free groundwater (two
label: BODY

text: mechanisms that can decrease Cr(VI) concentrations
label: BODY

text: in the contaminant plume), and potentially for distin-
label: BODY

text: guishing between industrial and natural sources of Cr
label: BODY

text: (VI). Sources of Cr used for industrial purposes are
label: BODY

text: likely to be Cr ore deposits and minerals, which con-
label: BODY

text: sistently have d53/52Cr values close to 0‰ relative to
label: BODY

text: NIST 979 (Ellis et al. 2002; Schoenberg et al. 2008).
label: BODY

text: In contrast, naturally occurring Cr in groundwater dis-
label: BODY

text: plays a range of values (d53/52Cr: +1.0 to +5.8‰; Ellis
label: BODY

text: et al. 2002; Izbicki et al. 2008). These values likely
label: BODY

text: reﬂect fractionation during oxidation of Cr(III) on
label: BODY

text: manganese oxides and fractionation during subsequent
label: BODY

text: reduction of Cr(VI) along groundwater ﬂowpaths fol-
label: BODY

text: lowing mobilization of the highly soluble Cr(VI) from
label: BODY

text: mineral surface sorption sites. Thus under favorable
label: BODY

text: conditions the natural and industrial Cr pools at a con-
label: BODY

text: taminated site may have different d53/52Cr values.
label: BODY

text: In order to test the usefulness of Cr stable isotopes
label: BODY

text: for Cr contamination source assessment and process
label: BODY

text: identiﬁcation at a well-studied contaminated site, a
label: BODY

text: pilot study (CH2MHill 2007) was carried out at the
label: BODY

text: Paciﬁc Gas & Electric (PG&E) Compressor Facility
label: BODY

text: in Hinkley, California, made famous in the movie
label: BODY

text: “Erin Brockovich.” From 1952 to 1966, waste water
label: BODY

text: containing Cr(VI) used as an anti-corrosive in the
label: BODY

text: cooling towers leaked into the underlying sandy
label: BODY

text: aquifer, creating a plume of Cr(VI)-contaminated
label: BODY

text: groundwater that by 2000 had migrated nearly
label: BODY

text: 2 miles downgradient from the facility. Groundwater
label: BODY

text: samples from immediately adjacent to the facility,
label: BODY

text: from within the plume, and of regional groundwater
label: BODY

text: collected well away from the plume were analyzed
label: BODY

text: for Cr stable isotope composition (Bullen 2007). As
label: BODY

text: shown in Fig. 10.3, the data plot along a well-
label: BODY

text: organized trend, with near-facility (contaminant) and
label: BODY

text: regional groundwaters deﬁning the extremes, while
label: BODY

text: samples from the contaminant plume plot in between.
label: BODY

text: There is no question that in this particular case, the
label: BODY

text: Cr stable isotopes clearly distinguish the natural and
label: BODY

text: anthropogenic Cr(VI) end-members.
label: BODY

text: It is less clear how the samples collected from
label: BODY

text: the contaminant plume obtained their compositions
label: BODY

text: in d53/52Cr-Cr concentration space. For example, as
label: BODY

text: shown in Fig. 10.3 the plume sample data all lie well
label: BODY

text: to the low-Cr side of model trends describing both
label: BODY

text: abiotic and microbially-mediated Cr(VI) reduction
label: BODY

text: (Ellis et al. 2002; Sikora et al. 2008) and well to the
label: BODY

text: high-d53/52Cr side of the model trend for advective
label: BODY

text: mixing
label: BODY

text: between
label: BODY

text: near-facility
label: BODY

text: contaminant
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: regional groundwaters, suggesting that neither Cr(VI)
label: BODY

text: reduction nor advective mixing alone is able to
label: BODY

text: account for those compositions. However, some com-
label: BODY

text: bination of Cr(VI) reduction and advective mixing
label: BODY

text: could account for the plume sample compositions,
label: BODY

text: and a scenario that is at least consistent with ﬁeld
label: BODY

text: relations (Bullen 2007) is shown in Fig. 10.3. In this
label: BODY

text: scenario, Cr(VI) at the front and margins of the migrat-
label: BODY

text: ing contaminant plume would come into contact with
label: BODY

text: the limited reductant (e.g. ferrous iron, organic matter)
label: BODY

text: in this aquifer, allowing small amounts of Cr(VI)
label: BODY

text: reduction to occur and driving remnant Cr(VI) compo-
label: BODY

text: sitions along the model Cr(VI) reduction vectors. At
label: BODY

text: the same time, advective mixing with regional ground-
label: BODY

text: waters at the plume front and margins would shift
label: BODY

text: remnant Cr(VI) compositions to the low-Cr side of
label: BODY

text: the model Cr(VI) reduction vectors (e.g. along trajec-
label: BODY

text: tories similar to the lines labeled “plume front Cr(VI)
label: BODY

text: reduction-mixing” in Fig. 10.3). After 40 years of
label: BODY

text: plume migration, one could imagine an array of devel-
label: BODY

text: oped plume front and margin groundwater composi-
label: BODY

text: tions similar to region “FM” in Fig. 10.3. This range of
label: BODY

text: plume front and margin groundwater compositions
label: BODY

text: would result from speciﬁc evolutionary trends that
label: BODY

text: depend on the relative amount of Cr(VI) reduction
label: BODY

text: and advective mixing with regional groundwater that
label: BODY

text: occurred at any particular position along the plume
label: BODY

text: front or margin. In this scenario, the actual plume
label: BODY

text: sample array would develop by advective mixing
label: BODY

text: between these hypothesized plume front and margin
label: BODY

text: groundwaters and the contaminated groundwater
label: BODY

text: Stable Isotopes of Transition and Post-Transition Metals as Tracers in Environmental Studies
label: BODY

text: within the plume body itself. Note that extremely
label: BODY

text: careful, discrete depth sampling at the plume front
label: BODY

text: and margins would be necessary to conﬁrm the exis-
label: BODY

text: tence and determine the exact shape of the “FM”
label: BODY

text: region hypothesized in Fig. 10.3, but such an effort
label: BODY

text: would be useful for supporting the validity of this
label: BODY

text: proposed scenario.
label: BODY

text: In their detailed time-series study of a point-source
label: BODY

text: Cr contamination plume emanating from a Cr plating
label: BODY

text: facility in Berkeley, California, Berna et al. (2010)
label: BODY

text: observed a similar trend for plume groundwater
label: BODY

text: samples in d53/52Cr-Cr concentration space, such that
label: BODY

text: the plume samples had intermediate compositions
label: BODY

text: between vectors describing Cr(VI) reduction and
label: BODY

text: advective mixing with Cr-free groundwater. Although
label: BODY

text: they concluded that Cr(VI) reduction and advective
label: BODY

text: mixing were important processes determining the
label: BODY

text: composition of the plume groundwater samples, they
label: BODY

text: likewise pointed to the potential importance of hetero-
label: BODY

text: geneous Cr(VI) reduction in the aquifer. Their labora-
label: BODY

text: tory incubation experiments had demonstrated that Cr
label: BODY

text: (VI) reduction was limited to greenish, ﬁne-grained
label: BODY

text: lenses that are embedded in non-reducing aquifer
label: BODY

text: materials. They proposed that total reduction of
label: BODY

text: small pools of Cr(VI) in the greenish lenses would
label: BODY

text: decrease the amount of Cr(VI) measured in a down-
label: BODY

text: gradient sampling well, but would not change the d53/
label: BODY

text: 52Cr value of the remaining Cr(VI) transported
label: BODY

text: through the non-reducing aquifer materials. As a
label: BODY

text: result, the d53/52Cr value of groundwater sampled
label: BODY

text: along the plume is not as high and the d53/52Cr value
label: BODY

text: of Cr(III) immobilized on the aquifer sediment
label: BODY

text: is not as low as would be predicted for a system
label: BODY

text: where reduction occurs homogeneously throughout
label: BODY

text: the aquifer. As at Hinkley, careful discrete depth
label: BODY

text: sampling would help to determine the inﬂuence of
label: BODY

text: aquifer heterogeneity on Cr(VI) reduction effective-
label: BODY

text: ness and measured d53/52Cr values.
label: BODY

text: 10.4.1.2 Sources of Zinc in River Water
label: BODY

text: As described above in the overview on Zn, there are
label: BODY

text: several processes that may result in Zn stable isotope
label: BODY

text: fractionation including biological incorporation, abi-
label: BODY

text: otic adsorption, chemical diffusion and industrial pro-
label: BODY

text: cessing. Although Zn is not a highly toxic metal it does
label: BODY

text: provide a useful index of environmental contamina-
label: BODY

text: tion because it is commonly associated with toxic
label: BODY

text: metals such as Cd and Pb. Thus Zn stable isotopes
label: BODY

text: may be useful for distinguishing natural and anthro-
label: BODY

text: pogenic sources of metals in both hydrologic and
label: BODY

text: atmospheric systems.
label: BODY

text: An interesting example of the usefulness of Zn
label: BODY

text: isotopes to trace contaminant sources is the work of
label: BODY

text: Chen et al. (2008, 2009) who studied Zn isotope sys-
label: BODY

text: tematics of the Seine River of France. The Seine River
label: BODY

text: is one of the most anthropogenically impacted rivers in
label: BODY

text: Europe, with high relative concentrations of metals
label: BODY

text: (Zn, Cu, Pb, Ni, etc.) in dissolved and suspended
label: BODY

text: loads compared to large rivers of the world (Chen
label: BODY

text: et al. 2009). For their study, these workers sampled
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 10.4.1.3 Tracing Sources of Metals in Dust Using
label: BODY

text: a Multi-Tracer Approach
label: BODY

text: Inhalation of dust particles is potentially a primary
label: BODY

text: delivery mechanism of toxic metals to humans. More-
label: BODY

text: over, incorporation of deposited dust in soil can allow
label: BODY

text: the metals to become available to plants, providing an
label: BODY

text: additional source of metal loading to crops. There are
label: BODY

text: many possible sources of transition and post-transition
label: BODY

text: metals that could supply the metal content of dust. The
label: BODY

text: major contributors are likely to include metal reﬁning
label: BODY

text: and smelting, coal combustion ﬂy ash and residues,
label: BODY

text: petroleum burning and particularly vehicle emissions,
label: BODY

text: municipal waste incineration, scrap metal deterioration,
label: BODY

text: and wood burning. Early approaches for identifying
label: BODY

text: dust sources relied on tracers such as concentration
label: BODY

text: ratios of metals and surrogates such as strontium iso-
label: BODY

text: topes that might be able to tie the dust back to speciﬁc
label: BODY

text: geologic or regional sources. While there have been
label: BODY

text: numerous examples of success with this approach,
label: BODY

text: environmental isotope scientists have been exploring
label: BODY

text: whether the stable isotope composition of the transition
label: BODY

text: and post-transition metals might be more directly use-
label: BODY

text: ful for ﬁngerprinting the sources of the metals in dust.
label: BODY

text: Of the potential sources for these metals listed
label: BODY

text: above, metal reﬁning and smelting have received the
label: BODY

text: most attention, mainly for Zn and Cd, pointing to
label: BODY

text: the unique physical characteristics of these two post-
label: BODY

text: transition metals. As noted above in the overview on
label: BODY

text: these elements, their boiling points are sufﬁciently low
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Cd, and Hg, along with unfractionated compositions
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: those metals in dust samples.

text: The Zn and Cd stable isotope compositions of
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 10.4.2 Metal Redox Cycles
label: BODY

text: The common association of changes in redox status of
label: BODY

text: the transition and post-transition metals with isotope
label: BODY

text: fractionation between oxidized and reduced states
label: BODY

text: points to the potentially powerful application of
label: BODY

text: the isotopes as tracers of redox cycles in natural sys-
label: BODY

text: tems. Isotopes can be used, for example, to distinguish
label: BODY

text: between biological and geochemical processes, such
label: BODY

text: as microbial reduction and inorganic oxidation, and
label: BODY

text: physical processes, such as advective mixing and dif-
label: BODY

text: fusion, to explain chemical and isotopic composition
label: BODY

text: gradients in hydrologic systems.
label: BODY

text: Teutsch et al. (2009) used Fe isotopes to study the
label: BODY

text: Fe cycle across the oxic-anoxic boundary of mero-
label: BODY

text: mictic Lake Nyos, Cameroon, the site of a sudden
label: BODY

text: catastrophic release of CO2 in 1986 that killed about
label: BODY

text: 1,700 people. To avoid the recurrence of catastrophic
label: BODY

text: outgassing of CO2 that is supplied by groundwater to
label: BODY

text: the lake bottom, the lake is now artiﬁcially degassed
label: BODY

text: by a tube that drains deep water to the surface (Kling
label: BODY

text: et al. 2005). The degassing system spreads deep water
label: BODY

text: with concentrations of dissolved Fe(II) in a high jet
label: BODY

text: over the lake, causing immediate oxidation of the Fe
label: BODY

text: (II) to Fe(III)-oxyhydroxide particulate which then
label: BODY

text: settles into the lake. Concentrations of dissolved
label: BODY

text: Fe(II) in the oxic surface waters are negligible, but
label: BODY

text: sharply increase as particles settle across the oxic-
label: BODY

text: anoxic boundary at depth. Partial reduction of the
label: BODY

text: Fe(III)-rich particles at this boundary releases Fe(II)
label: BODY

text: to solution, which then diffuses upwards into the
label: BODY

text: oxic zone where it is re-oxidized to form Fe(III)-
label: BODY

text: oxyhydroxides which settle back to the oxic-anoxic
label: BODY

text: boundary, and the cycle continues.
label: BODY

text: Depth proﬁles sampled in the lake revealed a sharp
label: BODY

text: increase in both dissolved Fe(II) concentrations
label: BODY

text: and d57/54Fe values in a thin zone across the oxic-
label: BODY

text: anoxic boundary. Using a calibrated one dimensional
label: BODY

text: reaction-transport model that considered the isotopic
label: BODY

text: signatures of dissolved Fe(II) and the settling of Fe
label: BODY

text: (III)-rich particles, the settling ﬂuxes of the particles
label: BODY

text: and
label: BODY

text: the
label: BODY

text: dissolved
label: BODY

text: Fe(II)
label: BODY

text: concentration
label: BODY

text: proﬁles,
label: BODY

text: Teutsch et al. (2009) showed that the sharp increase
label: BODY

text: in d57/54Fe values is caused by isotopic fractionation
label: BODY

text: associated with dissimilatory Fe(III) reduction across
label: BODY

text: the oxic-anoxic boundary. They further showed that
label: BODY

text: the continued shift toward even greater d57/54Fe values
label: BODY

text: below the oxic-anoxic boundary is due to vertical
label: BODY

text: mixing of Fe–rich lake bottom water that has high-
label: BODY

text: d57/54Fe values, perhaps due to precipitation of
label: BODY

text: siderite. In this study, isotopic analyses coupled to
label: BODY

text: modeling
label: BODY

text: proved
label: BODY

text: invaluable
label: BODY

text: for
label: BODY

text: identifying
label: BODY

text: the

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Isotopes can likewise be used to assess paleoredox
label: BODY

text: conditions in water bodies, for example by looking at
label: BODY

text: variations of the redox-sensitive Mo isotope composi-
label: BODY

text: tion of sediments. In oxic settings, Mo isotopes are
label: BODY

text: fractionated during adsorption of Mo to ferroman-
label: BODY

text: ganese oxides, with light isotopes preferentially
label: BODY

text: associated with the solids. Experimental work under
label: BODY

text: oxidizing conditions has shown that d97/95Mo of aque-
label: BODY

text: ous Mo in seawater is 2.7‰ greater than that of
label: BODY

text: adsorbed Mo on sediment (Barling et al. 2001;
label: BODY

text: Barling and Anbar 2004; Wasylenki et al. 2008). As
label: BODY

text: waters progress from oxic to suboxic to anoxic to
label: BODY

text: euxinic (i.e. sulﬁdic) conditions, MoO4
label: BODY

text: 2- is converted
label: BODY

text: to MoS4
label: BODY

text: 2- which readily adsorbs to particles allowing
label: BODY

text: aqueous Mo to be more effectively removed to the
label: BODY

text: sediment (Poulson et al. 2006; Neubert et al. 2008).
label: BODY

text: The net result is that the isotopic contrast between
label: BODY

text: aqueous and sorbed Mo is greatest at slightly reducing
label: BODY

text: conditions and low sedimentation rates, but decreases
label: BODY

text: with increasingly reducing and sulﬁdic conditions due
label: BODY

text: to increasingly more quantitative removal of Mo from
label: BODY

text: solution.
label: BODY

text: This concept was used by Siebert et al. (2006) to
label: BODY

text: account for differences in the average Mo isotope
label: BODY

text: composition of sediment proﬁles from continental mar-
label: BODY

text: gin settings. These workers recognized a co-variation
label: BODY

text: between the Mo isotope composition of the sediments
label: BODY

text: and the rate of both authigenic Mo accumulation and
label: BODY

text: organic carbon oxidation and burial under reducing
label: BODY

text: conditions. Malinovsky et al. (2007) tried the same
label: BODY

text: approach to understand paleoredox cycles in lakes
label: BODY

text: from northern Sweden and northwestern Russia, where
label: BODY

text: variations of Mo isotope composition in the sediments
label: BODY

text: could be attributed to both redox status of the water
label: BODY

text: column and isotopically variable input of Mo into the
label: BODY

text: lakes due to Mo isotopic heterogeneity of bedrock in
label: BODY

text: the drainage basins. This latter study points to the need
label: BODY

text: for rigorous source term characterization, particularly
label: BODY

text: as study site size decreases from global to local scale.
label: BODY

text: An area of applied research where transition and
label: BODY

text: post-transition metal stable isotopes are increasingly
label: BODY

text: being used is to understand sedimentary and low tem-
label: BODY

text: perature hydrothermal metal redox cycling, where
label: BODY

text: both inorganic and biological redox processes can
label: BODY

text: cause isotope fractionation. For example, Asael et al.
label: BODY

text: (2007) used Cu stable isotopes to understand Cu redox
label: BODY

text: cycling and mass transfer functions during sequential
label: BODY

text: cycles of low temperature alteration of igneous copper
label: BODY

text: porphyries, marine sedimentary diagenesis and epige-
label: BODY

text: netic mobilization of Cu in sandstones at a site of
label: BODY

text: historic Cu mining in southern Israel. As predicted
label: BODY

text: by theory and experiment, they found that d65/63Cu
label: BODY

text: values of Cu(I)-sulﬁdes in the stratiform sediment-
label: BODY

text: hosted Cu deposits are signiﬁcantly lower than those
label: BODY

text: of coexisting Cu(II)-carbonates and hydroxides. Cou-
label: BODY

text: pling the Cu isotope composition of the minerals to
label: BODY

text: a mass balance model revealed that the main Cu reser-
label: BODY

text: voir of the ore body is a sandstone-shale sequence and
label: BODY

text: that the importance of Cu-sulﬁde reservoirs is small,
label: BODY

text: consistent with ﬁeld observations. Thus most of the Cu
label: BODY

text: transport occurred in relatively oxidized conditions,
label: BODY

text: the knowledge of which provides a novel tool for
label: BODY

text: exploration in the future.

text: 10.4.3 Plant Nutrition and Processes
label: BODY

text: Within Plants
label: BODY

text: Numerous transition and post-transition metals play
label: BODY

text: important chemical roles in plant nutrition (Marschner
label: BODY

text: 1995). For example, of the metals discussed in this
label: BODY

text: chapter, Fe is essential for chlorophyll development
label: BODY

text: and function, assists in energy transfer functions
label: BODY

text: and redox reactions, is an important constituent of
label: BODY

text: enzymes and participates in nitrogen ﬁxation. Zinc is
label: BODY

text: important for carbohydrate and protein metabolism,
label: BODY

text: pollen formation, and general disease resistance, and
label: BODY

text: is a structural constituent or regulatory co-factor of
label: BODY

text: numerous plant enzymes. Molybdenum, Cu and Ni
label: BODY

text: each play additional important physiological roles in
label: BODY

text: plant nutrition, while excesses can lead to a variety of
label: BODY

text: toxic effects on plant vitality. Using the stable iso-
label: BODY

text: topes of these metals as indicators of metal sources
label: BODY

text: and cycling processes, and perhaps to reveal the
label: BODY

text: onset of metal toxicity, is an emerging ﬁeld in isotope
label: BODY

text: biogeoscience.
label: BODY

text: As pointed out by von Blanckenburg et al. (2009),
label: BODY

text: the metabolic processes that control the behavior
label: BODY

text: of metals in plants can be envisaged as a gigantic
label: BODY

text: geochemical pump that continuously moves metals
label: BODY

text: between reservoirs. As plants move metals from soils
label: BODY

text: into roots and along the transpiration stream, the
label: BODY

text: metals are cycled through a variety of chemical spe-
label: BODY

text: cies
label: BODY

text: via
label: BODY

text: processes
label: BODY

text: that
label: BODY

text: can
label: BODY

text: lead
label: BODY

text: isotope
label: BODY

text: T.D. Bullen
label: BODY

text: fractionation. During the past several years, for the
label: BODY

text: metals discussed here stable isotope fractionation in
label: BODY

text: higher plants has been demonstrated for Fe and Zn
label: BODY

text: (Weiss et al. 2005; Guelke and von Blanckenburg
label: BODY

text: 2007; Viers et al. 2007; Moynier et al. 2008; Kiczka
label: BODY

text: et al. 2010). This is an intriguing pair of metals to
label: BODY

text: consider, as the isotope fractionations observed in
label: BODY

text: plants are largely controlled by redox status for Fe,
label: BODY

text: and by complexation chemistry for Zn.
label: BODY

text: Plants have developed two different strategies
label: BODY

text: for transporting Fe from soils into roots. Roots of
label: BODY

text: dicotyledons and nongraminaceous monocotyledons
label: BODY

text: (“strategy I plants”, e.g. pea, bean) release protons
label: BODY

text: into the rhizosphere, promoting dissolution of Fe(III)
label: BODY

text: precipitates, and activating membrane-bound enzymes
label: BODY

text: that reduce chelate-bound Fe(III). The reduced Fe is
label: BODY

text: then transported across the root plasma membrane by
label: BODY

text: unspeciﬁc metal transporters (Briat et al. 2007). Partial
label: BODY

text: reduction of an Fe(III)-solid produces aqueous Fe(II)
label: BODY

text: with an 56Fe/54Fe ratio that is approximately 1–1.5‰
label: BODY

text: less than that in the remaining Fe(III)-solid (Johnson
label: BODY

text: et al. 2004). As a consequence, the Fe(II) that crosses
label: BODY

text: the root plasma membrane, and thus the pool of Fe in
label: BODY

text: a strategy I plant, is lighter than the soil Fe pool.
label: BODY

text: In contrast, roots of graminaceous plant species
label: BODY

text: (“strategy II plants”, e.g. maize, wheat) can release
label: BODY

text: phytosiderophores into the rhizosphere, which form
label: BODY

text: complexes with Fe(III) (Romheld and Marschner
label: BODY

text: 1986; Kraemer et al. 2006). These Fe(III)-complexes
label: BODY

text: are then transported across the root plasma membrane
label: BODY

text: by a specialized class of transport proteins, but due to
label: BODY

text: lack of reduction, the pool of Fe(III) in a strategy II
label: BODY

text: plant has the same Fe isotope composition as the soil
label: BODY

text: Fe pool.
label: BODY

text: The results of two studies of Fe isotope variability
label: BODY

text: in plants are shown in Fig. 10.6. In a variety of strategy
label: BODY

text: I plants studied by Guelke and von Blanckenburg
label: BODY

text: (2007), d56/54Fe values of tissues decreased from
label: BODY

text: soils to stems, from stems to leaves and from leaves
label: BODY

text: to seeds. In contrast, all tissues in their strategy II
label: BODY

text: plants had similar d56/54Fe values, which they attrib-
label: BODY

text: uted to differences in the way that Fe is translocated in
label: BODY

text: the two plant types. These results are consistent with
label: BODY

text: the different Fe uptake and transport processes pro-
label: BODY

text: posed above for strategy I and strategy II plants.
label: BODY

text: Kiczka et al. (2010), working with strategy I and II
label: BODY

text: plants collected from a recently deglaciated site, iden-
label: BODY

text: tiﬁed several reaction points along the translocation
label: BODY

text: stream of both plant types where Fe(III) reduction and
label: BODY

text: thus isotope fractionation might occur, including
label: BODY

text: between the root symplast and apoplast, between the
label: BODY

text: leaf cytoplasm and the xylem, and between the phloem
label: BODY

text: and the leaf cytoplasm, at each step moving lighter Fe
label: BODY

text: along the transpiration stream. However, in contrast to
label: BODY

text: the results of Guelke and von Blanckenburg (2007),
label: BODY

text: Kiczka et al. (2010) observed similar Fe isotope pat-
label: BODY

text: terns in their strategy I and II plants, with d56/54Fe
label: BODY

text: values generally increasing from root stele to stem
label: BODY

text: to leaf. To explain this discrepancy, they pointed to
label: BODY

text: previous studies suggesting that release of sidero-
label: BODY

text: phores by strategy II plants into the rhizosphere is
label: BODY

text: suppressed under Fe-rich soil conditions similar to
label: BODY

text: Fig. 10.6 d56/54Fe values for a variety of plant tissues. Values
label: BODY

text: for lettuce and soybean (Strategy I) and wheat (Strategy II) are
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: stream
label: BODY

text: Stable Isotopes of Transition and Post-Transition Metals as Tracers in Environmental Studies
label: BODY

text: those at their ﬁeld site (Marschner 1995), and suggest-
label: BODY

text: ing that strategy I and II plants mobilize and transport
label: BODY

text: Fe similarly under such conditions (Charlson and
label: BODY

text: Shoemaker 2006).
label: BODY

text: In the case of Zn, dissolution of Fe(III) solids in the
label: BODY

text: soil by protons released from plant roots results in
label: BODY

text: release of Zn that is adsorbed on the Fe(III) solids.
label: BODY

text: Subsequent uptake of Zn by roots depends only on the
label: BODY

text: induction of speciﬁc Zn transporters, which belong to
label: BODY

text: the same protein family as the Fe transporters (Kramer
label: BODY

text: et al. 2007). Likewise, the release of phytosidero-
label: BODY

text: phores beneﬁts the acquisition of Zn (Suzuki et al.
label: BODY

text: 2006). Apparently the transport of Fe and Zn to plant
label: BODY

text: roots is closely linked. Zn isotope variability within
label: BODY

text: plants appears to be fairly straightforward and similar
label: BODY

text: for strategy I and strategy II plants, based on several
label: BODY

text: laboratory and ﬁeld based studies (Weiss et al. 2005;
label: BODY

text: Viers et al. 2007; Moynier et al. 2008). Roots tend
label: BODY

text: have the heaviest Zn, probably reﬂecting the preferen-
label: BODY

text: tial adsorption of heavy Zn onto the root and plaque
label: BODY

text: surfaces. However it should be noted that the possibil-
label: BODY

text: ity of Zn isotope contrast between the root cortex and
label: BODY

text: stele of plants has yet to be explored, as has been done
label: BODY

text: for Fe isotopes (Kiczka et al. 2010). Shoots have
label: BODY

text: similar to lesser d66/64Zn values than bulk roots, and
label: BODY

text: leaves invariably contain the lightest Zn in the plants.
label: BODY

text: These observations are consistent with light Zn iso-
label: BODY

text: topes being transported preferentially during nutrient
label: BODY

text: exchange along the cell walls of the xylem although it
label: BODY

text: is unclear at this stage whether this is a kinetic or an
label: BODY

text: equilibrium process (von Blanckenburg et al. 2009).
label: BODY

text: There clearly remains much to be done to under-
label: BODY

text: stand the causes of transition and post-transition metal
label: BODY

text: stable isotope fractionation in plants, and certainly the
label: BODY

text: remaining metals deserve at least a thorough recon-
label: BODY

text: naissance for a variety of plant species and ﬁeld
label: BODY

text: situations. To date, much of the work has aimed at
label: BODY

text: explaining observed variations of isotope composition
label: BODY

text: in terms of known plant processes. With greater under-
label: BODY

text: standing, future work will gradually shift toward using
label: BODY

text: the isotopes to identify as yet unknown or uncon-
label: BODY

text: strained processes in plants.

text: 10.4.4 Biosignatures
label: BODY

text: One of the most enduring hopes and goals of metal
label: BODY

text: stable isotope biogeochemistry is to be able to use the
label: BODY

text: isotopes as biosignatures, by developing either single
label: BODY

text: or multi-tracer tests that could be applied to a natural
label: BODY

text: system to decipher a biological inﬂuence on its origins.
label: BODY

text: A recurring theme in metal stable isotope studies of
label: BODY

text: biological systems is that biological activities that result
label: BODY

text: in signiﬁcant isotope fractionation generally involve
label: BODY

text: preferential processing of lighter isotopes from the
label: BODY

text: metal source pool into and within the biological materi-
label: BODY

text: als (e.g. Zhu et al. 2002; Bermin et al. 2006; Johnson
label: BODY

text: et al. 2008; Eisenhauer et al. 2009). Indeed, in the early
label: BODY

text: days of the transition and post-transition metal stable
label: BODY

text: isotope data explosion (i.e. the late 1990s), the general
label: BODY

text: thinking was that most metal stable isotope fraction-
label: BODY

text: ation observed in nature would be due to biological
label: BODY

text: processing (e.g. Beard and Johnson 1999). This think-
label: BODY

text: ing led to pioneering attempts to constrain experimen-
label: BODY

text: tally an Fe isotope biosignature (Beard et al. 1999),
label: BODY

text: but likewise inspired early attempts to demonstrate the
label: BODY

text: importance of inorganic processes that could fractionate
label: BODY

text: Fe isotopes both in the laboratory (e.g. Anbar et al.
label: BODY

text: 2000) and in natural settings (e.g. Bullen et al. 2001).
label: BODY

text: We now realize that ranges of metal stable isotope
label: BODY

text: fractionation caused by inorganic processes can exceed
label: BODY

text: and overlap those produced by biological processing,
label: BODY

text: making development of robust metal stable isotope
label: BODY

text: biosignature tools a challenge but also an exceptional
label: BODY

text: research opportunity.
label: BODY

text: Given the early and persistent focus on the isotope
label: BODY

text: systematics of Fe, it is not surprising that the greatest
label: BODY

text: progress toward development of a metal stable isotope
label: BODY

text: biosignature has been for Fe, at least for early Earth
label: BODY

text: environments. As stressed by Johnson et al. (2008), the
label: BODY

text: ﬂuxes of mobilized Fe must have been far greater in
label: BODY

text: the Archean and early Proterozoic because of the
label: BODY

text: enormous amount of Fe-rich sediments (e.g. banded
label: BODY

text: iron formations) that were deposited in that time span.
label: BODY

text: The Fe isotope compostion of those sediments is
label: BODY

text: highly variable compared to igneous rocks, implying
label: BODY

text: that the processes responsible for fractionating Fe
label: BODY

text: must have been especially active and variable in extent
label: BODY

text: during that time span. Because microbial dissimilatory
label: BODY

text: Fe reduction (DIR) appears to be the most important
label: BODY

text: process capable of producing large quantities of isoto-
label: BODY

text: pically light Fe, by an order of magnitude or more
label: BODY

text: compared to inorganic processes, DIR is likely to have
label: BODY

text: been the dominant process affecting Fe during that
label: BODY

text: time span.
label: BODY

text: In this case, the effectiveness of the Fe isotope
label: BODY

text: biosignature depended on knowledge of the relative
label: BODY

text: sizes of the reduced and oxidized Fe pools during early
label: BODY

text: T.D. Bullen
label: BODY

text: Earth history. If we are going to be able to use Fe
label: BODY

text: isotopes to detect a record of DIR in other environ-
label: BODY

text: ments (e.g. in the search for life on Mars and other
label: BODY

text: planetary bodies), we must be able to assess the size of
label: BODY

text: those pools in those environments as well. Conﬁdence
label: BODY

text: in the approach will increase as more terrestrial ﬁeld
label: BODY

text: sites are studied. A promising example from modern
label: BODY

text: Earth comes from the work of Severmann et al.
label: BODY

text: (2008), who used Fe isotopes to support their conten-
label: BODY

text: tion that DIR coupled to Fe(II) oxidation in oxic shelf
label: BODY

text: sediments can account for the large amount of isotopi-
label: BODY

text: cally light Fe produced on the shelf and shuttled to the
label: BODY

text: euxinic basin of the Black Sea.
label: BODY

text: Biosignatures based on the other transition and post-
label: BODY

text: transition metal isotope systems have yet to be explored
label: BODY

text: as deeply as that based on Fe, but there are promising
label: BODY

text: signs for success. For example, Borrok et al. (2008)
label: BODY

text: documented a diel cycle for dissolved Zn concentra-
label: BODY

text: tions and d66/64Zn values in Prickly Pear Creek, which
label: BODY

text: drains a former mining district in the Boulder Batholith,
label: BODY

text: Montana, USA. They found that dissolved Zn concen-
label: BODY

text: trations and d66/64Zn values were inversely correlated,
label: BODY

text: with Zn at low concentrations in the daytime having
label: BODY

text: elevated d66/64Zn due to sequestration of light Zn in bed
label: BODY

text: sediments. Biological uptake of light Zn was invoked to
label: BODY

text: explain this relationship, since adsorption of Zn onto
label: BODY

text: amorphous Fe(III) oxides prevalent in bed sediments
label: BODY

text: preferentially concentrates heavy Zn onto sorption sites
label: BODY

text: (Balistrieri et al. 2008). As discussed above, Cameron
label: BODY

text: et al. (2009) demonstrated that methanogenic bacteria
label: BODY

text: cultured in the laboratory preferentially assimilate and
label: BODY

text: retain isotopically light Ni, while a wide range of geo-
label: BODY

text: logic materials have uniform Ni isotope composition.
label: BODY

text: Nickel isotopes are thus likely to become an important
label: BODY

text: biosignature of methanogenesis. And, as pointed out by
label: BODY

text: von Blanckenburg et al. (2009), plant tissues recycled
label: BODY

text: into soil generally have different metal stable isotope
label: BODY

text: composition than the growth medium, thus the upper soil
label: BODY

text: may retain a time-integrated metal isotope ﬁngerprint
label: BODY

text: of plant activity. New biosignatures are likely to emerge
label: BODY

text: as well understood biological systems are studied.
label: BODY

text: 10.5 Future Directions
label: BODY

text: As pointed out by Severmann and Anbar (2009), the
label: BODY

text: ﬁeld of metal stable isotope biogeochemistry emerged
label: BODY

text: primarily as an analytical pursuit driven by advances
label: BODY

text: in mass spectrometry applied to interesting geological
label: BODY

text: materials. Arguably, much of the work that has been
label: BODY

text: done to date with the transition and post-transition
label: BODY

text: metal stable isotopes has resulted in a better under-
label: BODY

text: standing of the isotope systems themselves rather than
label: BODY

text: the materials that have been measured. Many observed
label: BODY

text: variations in isotope composition have been explained
label: BODY

text: in terms of well understood physical, chemical and
label: BODY

text: biological processes, but isotope analyses have so far
label: BODY

text: rarely revealed some unanticipated or poorly under-
label: BODY

text: stood set of processes. On the other hand, useful
label: BODY

text: applications
label: BODY

text: pertinent
label: BODY

text: environmental
label: BODY

text: studies
label: BODY

text: are beginning to emerge: isotopic characteristics of
label: BODY

text: plant homeostasis are being established, multi-tracer
label: BODY

text: approaches for identifying metal sources are being
label: BODY

text: developed, biosignatures are being rigorously con-
label: BODY

text: strained through analysis of well understood geo-
label: BODY

text: logical and biological materials, and the isotopic
label: BODY

text: signatures of redox reactions are being characterized.
label: BODY

text: As understanding of metal stable isotope systematics
label: BODY

text: increases, it will become easier to think of novel ways
label: BODY

text: that isotopes can enhance understanding of complex
label: BODY

text: processes in environmental systems.
label: BODY

text: What should be clear from this chapter is that the
label: BODY

text: ﬁeld of transition and post-transition metal stable
label: BODY

text: isotope biogeochemistry is really just beginning to
label: BODY

text: mature, and that opportunities are abundant. Major
label: BODY

text: advances over the next several years are likely to
label: BODY

text: include: improving the routine precision and reproduc-
label: BODY

text: ibility of total procedural replicate measurements of
label: BODY

text: samples to the few hundredths of a per mil level;
label: BODY

text: developing robust multi-tracer approaches to identify
label: BODY

text: metal sources and pathways for forensic purposes;
label: BODY

text: looking for the unexpected isotope fractionation of
label: BODY

text: metals such as Ti and Ni in environmental systems;
label: BODY

text: expanding the list of robust biosignatures, including
label: BODY

text: the ﬁngerprint of anthropogenic activities; exploring
label: BODY

text: the metal stable isotope signals of global climate
label: BODY

text: change. This is only a partial list, but one where
label: BODY

text: success is likely to be realized through well-crafted
label: BODY

text: interdisciplinary efforts, careful selection of ﬁeld sites,
label: BODY

text: and clever laboratory- and ﬁeld-based experiments.
label: BODY
